Overview: LG Nexus 4 phone is the latest Google branded smartphone, thus replacing the Samsung Galaxy Nexus. The phone has a 4.7" capacitive touch screen with a resolution of 1280 x 768 pixels. This True HD IPS display has a Corning Gorilla Glass for protection. The LG Nexus 4 has a glass back similar to the one seen on the Apple iPhone 4. The phone runs on Android 4.2 Jelly Bean OS and is powered by a 1.5 GHz Quad-core Qualcomm Snapdragon S4 Krait Processor. Nexus 4 comes in two variants of internal storage, 8GB and 16GB. The powerful processor and display are complimented by 2GB of RAM. The Nexus 4 supports quad-band 2G and 3G networks and dual-band WiFi. The phone has Bluetooth 4.0, is NFC capable and has a microUSB port for entailing transfer of files efficiently.

The phone sports an 8 MP camera with auto focus, LED Flash and full HD video recording facility. The camera has additional features such a face detection, image stabilization, photo sphere and Geo-tagging. It gives an image resolution of 3264 x 2448 pixels and video recording of 1080p at 30 fps. This phone also offers a secondary front-facing camera of 1.3MP. The phone has a non-removable 2100 mAh standard Li-ion battery which provides 15 hours of talk time and 390 hours in stand-by mode. Its other features include GPS support, sensors like accelerometer, proximity and compass, active noise cancellation, image/video editor, voice memo and predictive text input.

Pros: Smaller form factor, good for one handed use
Sharp HD display with a pixel density of 318PPI
Cons: Glass build on the back makes the phone slippery and prone to drops

Overview: Apple unveils the Apple iPhone 13 pro max 1TB. The device has an Apple A15 Bionic chip. The display and cameras aren't that great but are decent.
Design and Display: The Apple iPhone 13 pro max 1TB features a 6.7 inch OLEDdisplay with a resolution of 1284x 2778 pixelsand a pixel density of 457ppi. The display comes with an aspect ratio of 19.5:9 and a refresh rate of 120 Hz. The device comes with IP68 water resistance.
Cameras: The Apple iPhone 13 pro max 1TB comes with a triple-camera system on the back with a 12MP primary sensor, a 12MP ultra wide-angle sensor, a 12 MP telephoto sensor, and a dual-LED flash. On the front, The device gets a 12MP selfie cam. AF Phase Detection, Auto Flash, Auto Focus, Bokeh Effect, Continuos Shooting, Deep Fusion, Exposure compensation, Face detection, Focus Pixels, Geo-tagging, High Dynamic Range mode (HDR), ISO control, Optical image stabilization, Red-eye Reduction, Sensor-shift Image Stabilization, Smart HDR, Time Lapse, Touch to focus, White balance presets are some of the many features that the camera supports.
Battery and Performance: The Apple iPhone 13 pro max 1TB is embedded with an Apple A15 Bionic processor and an Apple GPU (five-core graphics)GPU. The RAM and internal memory of the device are 6GB and 1TB respectively. The device doesn't support memory cards. A 4352mAh Li-ion battery comes with the device. It is having fast charging facility too.
Software and Connectivity: Apple iPhone 13 pro max 1TB comes with iOS out of the box. The smartphone gets connectivity options like 5G, dual sim VoLTE(Nano + eSIM), Wi-Fi 802.11, ax/b/g/n/n 5GHz, GPS, NFC, and Bluetooth 5.0. This device carries a lightning charging port

The cameras are pretty good in the budget. One can also enjoy multiple activities for a long time with the help of the battery back up.
Display and Camera: Apple iPhone 11 Pro Max comes with a 6.5-inch OLED display that comes with a screen resolution of 2,688 x 1,242 pixels and a pixel density of 456 PPI. It has 19.5:9 aspect ratio, which adds style to the vision.

For the camera, there are triple 12MP lenses at the primary level, which features AF Phase Detection, Auto Flash, Continuos Shooting, Bokeh Effect, Exposure compensation, Focus Pixels, Face detection, Geo-tagging, High Dynamic Range mode (HDR), ISO control, Optical image stabilization, Smart HDR, Touch to focus, Time Lapse, White balance presets, Phase Detection Autofocus (PDAF), Quad-LED True Tone Flash, OIS (Optical Image Stabilisation), Autofocus. Overview: As we near towards a perfect foldable smartphone, Samsung continues to evolve its flagship Galaxy Fold lineup. Soon after the launch of the Galaxy Z Fold 2 a few months back, the brand's already planning for the launch of its upcoming Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 3. This next-gen 5G foldable flagship is expected to offer a nearly perfect foldable experience compared to its predecessors. Speaking of the specs, the device will pack in a stunning display, great cameras along with a huge 4400 mAh battery, a Snapdragon 888 chipset, a beautiful design, and more.
Design and Display: The Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 3 will reportedly boast a powerful 7.6 inch Dynamic AMOLEDdisplay tipped with a resolution of 1768 x 2208 pixelsand a high pixel density of 372ppi to bring forth rich and vivid visuals. The additional 6.2-inch display is supposed to have a resolution of 832 x 2268 pixels. The bezel-less display will feature an immersive punch-hole design along with an ultra-smooth refresh rate of 120Hz.
Cameras: The Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 3 is supposed to ship with a triple rear camera setup having a 12MP primary camera, a 12MP telephoto lens, and a 12MP wide-angle sensor with LED flash onboard. Upfront, the smartphone is expected to feature a dual-camera setup with a 16MP primary wide-angle sensor and a 10MP selfie shooter, one on each of the screens. The camera will arrive with features like AF Phase Detection, Auto Flash, Auto Focus, Bokeh Effect, Continuos Shooting, Exposure compensation, Face detection, Geo-tagging, High Dynamic Range mode (HDR), ISO control, Optical image stabilization, Touch to focus, White balance presets
Battery and Performance: The Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 3 is touted to be driven by the Qualcomm Snapdragon 888chipset coupled with anAdreno 660 GPU to ensure powerful gaming performance. The device will come assembled with 12GB RAM paired with an internal storage capacity of 256GB, which sadly cannot be expanded. Fuelling the device will reportedly be a 4400mAh Li-ion battery with fast charging and wireless charging facility in the house.
Software and Connectivity: Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 3will runAndroid 11 out of the box. Coming to connectivity options, the smartphone will support a stack of features like 5G, Dual sim VoLTE (Nano + eSIM), Wi-Fi 802.11, a/ac/ax/b/g/n/n 5GHz, GPS, NFC, and Bluetooth 5.2. Adding more to the list, we will also get to see a side-mounted fingerprint sensor and a USB Type-C port.

Pros: 120Hz Dynamic AMOLED Display and beautiful design
Superb cameras and large internal storage
Huge 4400mAh Battery with Fast and Wireless Charging

Features: Super Retina HD Display, the smartest chip yet in a smartphone, and a state of the art dual camera system already make the latest offering from Apple a winner. Here is everything you can expect from the iPhone XS Max:
Design and Display: The iPhone XS Max sports the largest ever display on an iPhone with a size of 6.5 inches and a resolution of 1242 x 2688 pixels. The fingerprint scanner has been replaced by Face ID and the phone comes in three color variants of Space Grey, Silver, and Gold.
Camera: It comes with a set of dual 12 MP cameras powered with a Quad-LED dual-tone flash. The front camera is 7 MP and has the ability to record videos at 1080p at 60fps.
Performance and Storage: The phone is available in three storage models of 64 GB, 256 GB, and 512 GB, each accompanied by 4 GB RAM. The latest Apple A12 Bionic Chipset delivers enhanced performance and multitasking abilities.
Battery and Connectivity: The iPhone XS Max sports a powerful Li-Ion 3174 mAh battery that can handle up to 25 hours of talk time and 65 hours of music play.
Software and Platform: Apple has powered the iPhone XS Max with the latest iOS 12 that is loaded with advanced features like privacy protection, group face time, enhanced photo search, and the ability to create your own Animoji.

Cons: Lack of separate slot for the headphone jack
No fast charger in the box

Overview: The Samsung Galaxy F is one of a kind smartphone and there is the reason for this, it is the world’s first foldable smartphone. Speaking of features, it is loaded with all the features that you would for in a premium smartphone. We have strong processing front, huge storage space, and a superb set of cameras. This device is simply a class apart from other devices. So, if you have the budget you can totally go for this device.
Display and Configuration: The Samsung Galaxy F sports a 7.3 inch OLED display which is accompanied by a screen resolution of 1,536x2,152 pixels. The depth and clarity in the display can be attributed to a pixel density of 362 PPI.

The performance of the device is backed by an Octa-core processor which is split in the form of 2.84GHz, Single core + 2.42 Tri-core + 1.8Ghz Quad core, Kryo 485 processor seated upon a powerful Qualcomm Snapdragon 855 chipset. The high-end multitasking is taken care of by the massive 12GB RAM, while the Adreno 640 graphics processor enhances the gaming experience.
Camera and Battery: For photography, the device comes with a 12MP + 12MP + 16MP triple primary camera aided with features like phase detection autofocus and optical image stabilization. Also, the physical aperture of F1.5 along with the LED flash enhances the quality of the images, which can be ascertained with the 4,000 x 3,000 image resolution. The 10MP +8MP dual front camera provides some of the really stunning selfies.
The fuelling capacity of the device is backed by a 4,380 mAh Li-Polymer battery which also is attached with features like wireless and quick charging.

Overview: The iPhone 6 Plus was the first time when Apple jumped into the Phablet game. For years, Apple battled the large screen phones and stated the one handed use of phones as the primary reason for keeping the size of the iPhone always within 4-inch size. In several keynotes, Apple demonstrated how it was imperative that your thumb is able to reach out to the most extreme corner of the screen for easy usage and that is why they would not budge from the small screen size. However, with the demand for bigger phones on the uprise, Apple decided to give an option to its users with the iPhone 6 Plus. It was the iPhone for those who wanted a big device and made improvements in areas like battery life as well as the camera over the smaller iPhone 6. With the iPhone 6 Plus proving to be quite a hit and doing as well as any phablet out there, Apple gave the device the refresh it deserved with the iPhone 6s on September 9th, 2015.

Pros: Battery backup that will easily last all day
3D Touch is present which provides a unique way of interacting with the device
Lightening fast Touch ID to unlock the phone
Cons: Gripping the phone could be a problem if you have tiny hands
iOS does not take full advantage of a phablet sized big display

Overview: The iPhone 5c serves as the mid-range replacement model for the iPhone 5 in 2013. Internally, both handsets are almost the same  save for a bigger battery, a better front-facing camera and TD-LTE 4G support on the iPhone 5c. But the major change is the exterior shell, which now comes in five bright and youthful colours (thus the 'c' in iPhone 5c, which stands for 'colours'). It comes in White, Pink, Yellow, Blue and Green. Except for these above-mentioned changes, the rest remains the same. Its got the same 4-inch 1136 x 640 pixel IPS panel as the iPhone 5 and even the flagship iPhone 5s. It is powered by the A6 chip, has an 8 megapixel camera with f/2.4 aperture and a single LED flash. It comes with an aptly colourful and youthful-looking iOS 7 operating system. There are 16GB and 32GB of internal memory options. This is the 32GB variant.

Pros: Available in bright colour options unlike most phones
Compact and fits in hand well; Ideal for one handed usage

Cons: Average camera in low light conditions
Sluggish performance especially when upgraded to the latest iOS updates
Does not feel like a premium product that we are used to seeing from Apple

Overview: The LG G3 comes in less than a year after the well-received LG G2 was launched. While the G2 was packed to the gills with features, the LG G3 adds even more. For starters, the display is a little bigger at 5.5 inches, but now features an extremely high Quad HD (2560 x 1440 pixel) resolution. This bumps up the pixel density to a whopping 534PPI, making it one of the crispiest screens on the planet right now. Technically, the human eye cannot perceive the difference between pixels beyond 300 PPI pixel density, so despite the predecessor already having crossed that barrier (at 424PPI), we wonder how much of a benefit users will be able to notice with the bumped up resolution. Moving on, its powered by the Snapdragon 801 quad-core 2.5GHz chip, which is the gold-standard for Android flagships right now. Much like Gionees Elife E7, the LG G3 comes in two variants  a 2GB RAM unit with 16GB internal storage, and a 3GB RAM unit with 32GB memory. Whichever may be your preference, there is a microSD card slot on both models to accommodate up to 128GB more storage capacity. Design-wise, the G3 retains the placement of the power and volume buttons at the back of the device, around the camera lens. The metallic back now makes the phone look more appealing, and is available in more colour options (including Gold).

It maintains the 13MP camera sensor with Optical Image Stabilization at the back, but adds a two-tone flash (much like the iPhone 5s and the HTC One M8). But one unique camera feature is the laser-assisted auto-focus; a sensor on the other side of the camera lens that actually fires lasers to ascertain the distance between the subject, resulting in an extremely fast focusing and capturing of photos. Theres also a 1-watt speaker with a boost amplifier that should deliver loud and clear audio output. The 3000mAh battery is now removable and the phone now supports wireless charging too. LG has also flattened their software UI overlay which runs atop Android 4.4 KitKat.

They also sell the LG Circle Case; a flip cover with a circular viewing area when the flip is closed, and a special circular UI assists in using the phone without opening the flip cover. All in all, the LG G3 raises the bar for flagship Android phones for the year 2014, and technologies like Quad HD displays should become standard when the next batch of competition launches.

Pros: UI has received a facelift as compared to predecessor and looks a lot better
Overall the performance is very smooth
Camera performance in broad daylight is exceptional
Cons: Plastic build feels a little cheap
The volume and power buttons on the rear can take some time to get used to
Battery life takes a hit due to Quad HD display
The camera app can feel a bit too simplified

Overview: Asus took the wraps off the Zenfone AR at CES 2017. Interestingly, it is the second Google Tango-enabled smartphone.

The iPhone 6 Plus was the first time when Apple jumped into the Phablet game. For years, Apple battled the large screen phones and stated the one handed use of phones as the primary reason for keeping the size of the iPhone always within 4-inch size. In several keynotes, Apple demonstrated how it was imperative that your thumb is able to reach out to the most extreme corner of the screen for easy usage and that is why they would not budge from the small screen size. However, with the demand for bigger phones on the uprise, Apple decided to give an option to its users with the iPhone 6 Plus. It was the iPhone for those who wanted a big device and made improvements in areas like battery life as well as the camera over the smaller iPhone 6. With the iPhone 6 Plus proving to be quite a hit and doing as well as any phablet out there, Apple gave the device the refresh it deserved with the iPhone 6s on September 9th, 2015.

Overview: The 7th unveiling of the new iPhone saw yet another bump in the screen size that Apple offers on its phone. The iPhone 6 Plus has a 5.5 inches screen that manages to be as lean as 7.1mm. By far, that's the highlight, if you are wondering what changed since the iPhone 5s. But if you look beneath the hood, there is an all new Apple A8 processor (64 bit of course), a significantly improved 8MP camera with image and video stabilization and a new 128GB version. The iPhone 6 Plus comes in 16GB, 64GB and 128GB variants, that's right, no 32GB here. The larger form factor does add to the weight of the device and takes it to 172 gms from the 112 gms on the iPhone 5s. iPhone 6 Plus body has rounded edges, that takes us back to the feel of the original iPhones that we saw before the iPhone 4 introduced flat metal edges.

Apple also launched Apple Pay (a huge shot in the arm for NFC as a technology), a wallet to use your iPhone instead of plastic cards for payment and a new hardware category with the Apple Watch alongside the 4.7 inch iPhone 6 which comes in three variants. The iPhone 6 16GB, iPhone 6 64GB and the iPhone 6 128GB.

Overview: The Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge is like a more rounded and elder sibling of the Galaxy S7. Unlike last year, where the Samsung Galaxy S6 and the S6 Edge had pretty much the same size, the Galaxy S7 Edge is slightly bigger than the edge-free Galaxy S7. Other than the bigger size, there are not too many dissimilarities between the S7 and the S7 Edge.
Display & Design

The Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge brings the same glass and metal design as the Galaxy S7. However, thanks to a few more subtle curves especially at the bottom of the device, the S7 Edge is easier to pick off the surface without accidentally touching the edged display. It features a 5.5 inch Quad HD display giving it a pixel density of 534 PPI. Thanks to a high PPI and Super AMOLED display, the screen is perhaps one of the best that you will see in 2016 and the edges on both the sides only add to the viewing pleasure. The display is protected with Corning Gorilla Glass 4.
Hardware & Feature

The Samsung Galaxy S7 is an evolution of the Galaxy S6, where Samsung decided to drastically change the design and the construction materials of the flagship device. The Galaxy S7 take everything that was good with the S6, including a metal and glass construction and refines it. The result is a device that is truly the Android smartphone to beat in 2016.
Display & Design

The Samsung Galaxy S7 features a 5.1 inch Quad HD display with a Super AMOLED panel underneath. Thanks to the slightly smaller size and high resolution, the Galaxy S7 boasts of an incredibly high pixel density of 577PPI. It makes the text appear really sharp and crisp while pictures too have strong contrasts and punchy colours. The Galaxy S7 adds subtle curves to the glass and metal construction that we loved on the Galaxy S6, which makes the phone easier to pick up from a solid surface as well as adds much needed feeling of security when gripping it.
Hardware & Features

Powering the Galaxy S7 is Samsung’s in house chipset Exynos 8890. It is an Octa core SoC with Mali-T880 MP12 GPU. The international variant of the Samsung Galaxy S7 comes with Snapdragon 820, though in India, the units sold are with Exynos chipsets. Not only do you get a super fast processor, there is 4GB RAM inbuilt to help you race through your daily tasks. While the Galaxy S7 misses out on features like IR blaster seen on the S6, it more than makes up by offering water resistance thanks to an IP68 Rating. There is also a heart rate monitor and fingerprint scanner on the device. Galaxy S7 runs Android Marshmallow with TouchWiz on top.

Samsung is known for armoring their flagship devices with some of the best cameras in the mobile world and it is no different with the Galaxy S7. The device comes with a 12MP rear camera and a 5MP front facing snapper. Both the lens have f/1.7 aperture making them one of the best pair in its segment. The rear camera is capable of shooting 4K videos too. On the storage front, Samsung has brought the device in two storage variants: you have the 32GB version as well as the 64GB version. If that is not sufficient the SIM slot is a hybrid one, which allows you to slot in a Micro SD card to expand the storage.

Samsung has improved the battery game on the S7 when compared to S6. The bigger 3000mAh Li-Ion battery results in a slightly thicker device, but it is well worth the trade off for the improved battery life. Samsung has persisted with the Micro USB connector at the bottom and not C. The Galaxy S7 features a hybrid SIM slot, which lets you use either two SIM card, with dual standby and LTE support on both or swap one for a Micro SD card. The usual array of connectivities like Bluetooth, Wifi, GPS, NFC are present.

Samsung Galaxy S7 pits itself against the likes of as well as the flagship Nexus device in . You could also consider the other flagships of 2016 like the , as well as the as alternatives to the Galaxy S7.

Overview: The Xperia Z is an aggressive push into the smartphone market by Sony. The Z is a well-designed Android smartphone that is basked by quality hardware. A full HD display with a resolution of 1920x1080 on a 5" full touch-screen is only the beginning of this beast. The Xperia Z is powered by a 1.5GHz Quad-core processor and is supported by 2GB of RAM. With computing power exceeding many of our desktops and notebooks, the Z would set the standards for smartphones in 2013. Facing stiff competition from Samsung Galaxy SIII / Note II and HTC's One X series, Sony has thrown the Xperia Z as its response.

Sony hasn't left any stone unturned when it comes to features and spec sheet of the Z. The phone features a 13-megapixel camera that can record full HD videos (1080p), supports Micro SD card expansion along with the 16GB of internal storage and is powered by a 2370 mAh battery. Standard communications options like WiFi, Bluetooth, GPS and NFC are inbuilt. Amazingly the Xperia Z still weighs just 146 gms and is super slim at 7.9mm. Sony sure has packed in everything it needs to give Samsung a run for its money, a good design, specs that are very much up to date for 2013 and the oomph factor that was so far missing. Not just that, Sony has upped the game by making this flagship smartphone water & dust resistant (IP55 & IP57 certification), thus making the Z a rugged yet premium smartphone on the market.

Pros: The HD display on the phone is one of the best for its time
Premium build quality with glass and metallic build
Call quality is really good and the phone gets a very decent reception
Cons: The viewing angles on the phone are poor
Battery life is not that of a flagship phone
The back of the device is a fingerprint magnet thanks to the glass

Overview: The LG G2 is the successor to the Optimus G Pro handset from the Korean electronics giant. LG has fitted everything but the kitchen sink in the G2. Starting with the 5.2-inch 1080p IPS display, bringing the display density count to a high 424 PPI. Next is the top-of-the-line Snapdragon 800 chip, bringing sheer brute force at 2.26GHz of clock speed on all four cores. That's paired with 2GB of RAM and either 16GB or 32GB of internal storage. There's no microSD expansion. Design-wise, the most striking thing is the placement of the volume and power buttons at the back of the device, right under the camera sensor. The fastest internet technologies are thrown in  LTE, 3G with speeds of up to 42Mbps and WiFi 802.11ac too.

At the back rests a 13 megapixel camera with Optical Image Stabilization (OIS), enabling less blurry snaps and better low-light performance. It can also record 1080p HD videos at 60 frames per second. It also has multiple mics and noise-cancellation for capturing better sound. On the software side, LG has added a few interesting features  Guest mode allows you to hand over the phone to somebody without them looking at your personal stuff, Audio zooming captures audio of a subject better as compared to the background sounds. There's a reasonably large 3000mAh Lithium Polymer battery which should keep all this mighty hardware running for long. This is the LTE version, that supports the Band 40 that Indian networks like Reliance Jio or Airtel use (2300 MHz).

Pros: Double tap to power on and off the screen are really handy
Very reliable camera even in dim lights
Thin bezels make the experience of using the phone nice
Cons: The power and volume buttons at the back take some time getting used to
Plastic build makes the phone feel a little cheap
The plastic back picks up scratches rather easily

It's been a pattern since 2011, where Apple releases an 'S' version of an iPhone every other year. It retains the same design as its predecessor, but has one killer feature that sets the industry standard for years to come. The iPhone 4s had Siri, the iPhone 5s had Touch ID, and in 2015, the iPhone 6s and iPhone 6s Plus have 3D Touch. This year's iPhones look the same as the iPhone 6, with the exception of the new 'Rose Gold' (a.k.a light pink) colour option.

Pros: Excellent performance and virtually a lag free experience
Comfortable sized smartphone for one handed usage
Cons: The battery life could have been better

Overview: The Nexus 5 was a hit phone from LG in 2013, largely because it had all the hardware any power user could ask for, topped with buttery smooth performance of stock Android. More importantly, it didn't cost a lot of money. In 2014, Googles Nexus 6 made by Motorola was largely a dud because of its enormous size and high asking price. Since then, a lot of people had been asking for a redo of the Nexus 5. And in 2015, Google has done just that with the LG Nexus 5X. Although it is taller and wider by a few millimeters than the original, the Nexus 5X is still more comfortably-sized than its big brother, the Nexus 6P. The Nexus 5X is available in Carbon Black and Ice Blue in India but is available in Quartz White internationally.

The Samsung Galaxy A80 is a mid-range smartphone that comes with robust configuration and amazing features. Its large screen and sleek design make it more appealing to eyes. It also comes with a good set of cameras that clicks amazing pictures and holds sufficient battery backup. There is a fingerprint scanner, which enhances security.

The Vivo V15 Pro 8GB RAM comes with a selfie pop-up camera and leaves room for the display, which results in a vast viewing display without any interruptions. It flaunts a slim body with elegant nack finish that houses the rear camera setup. To ensure the privacy of the users at the same providing convenience, the fingerprint scanner in furnished in-display. In short, the company manages to bring a premium device in a mid-range budget.

The Honor 20 smartphone offers the best facilities for a smartphone device. The display offers a high screen resolution for better image and video clarity. The front and rear cameras offer bright, clear and enriched images and videos with the added LED flash facility for better low-light images. The smartphone offers great and efficient performance with the latest processor and decent RAM storage. The latest graphics card provide the best visual graphics.

The Nexus 5 is an LG-manufactured flagship phone from Google in 2013. It improves upon its predecessor, the Nexus 4, in many ways. Starting with the display  its got a 4.95-inch 1920 x 1080 pixel Full HD IPS panel covered with Gorilla Glass 3. Thats a whopping 445 PPI pixel density. The phone was so popular among the masses that Google worked with LG again to make the Nexus 5X as a tribute to the Nexus 5. It is powered by the latest-and-greatest Qualcomm Snapdragon 800 quad-core chip grunting at 2.3 GHz with an Adreno 330 graphics chip. Theres 2GB of RAM onboard and the Nexus 5 comes with either 16 or 32GB of internal storage (as with all recent Nexus handsets, theres no microSD card slot). Connectivity-wise, the Nexus 5 overcomes one of the shortcomings of the Nexus 4 with support for 4G (LTE) along with the latest WiFi 802.11ac and Bluetooth 4.0 support. Theres NFC and Wireless charging built-in as well.

Pros: Excellent display with accurate colour reproduction
Compact size of the smartphone makes it very handy to use
Being a Nexus device, guaranteed to be one of the fastest to receive Android updates

HTC Desire 816 is essentially a phablet featuring a 5.5 inches screen (1280x720 pixels) with a pixel density of 267PPI, which should deliver reasonable sharpness. Under the hood there is a 1.6GHz Quad-core Snapdragon 400 processor paired with 1.5 GB of RAM (its the same chip as the Moto G). The inbuilt 8GB memory can be expanded up to 128GB via high-capacity microSD cards.

In terms of camera, there is a 13 megapixel rear camera with flash while a 5 megapixel front camera for video calling and selfies. Since this is a mid-range device, HTC has not used the UltraPixel technology which is used in other flagship devices like the One. The camera is capable of recording Full HD videos at a resolution of 1080p. Apart from this, the looks are similar to HTC One, just that the aluminum body has been replaced by a plastic one but the dual frontal speakers have been retained. BlinkFeed and BoomSound are also available on this device, which adds to its utility.

The phone runs on the latest Android v4.4 KitKat, wrapped under the HTC's Sense User Interface. There is a non-removable 2600mAh battery which should juice this device for a day. The HTC Desire 816 is available in White, Grey & Orange colour.

Overview: LG Nexus 4 phone is the latest Google branded smartphone, thus replacing the Samsung Galaxy Nexus. The phone has a 4.7" capacitive touch screen with a resolution of 1280 x 768 pixels. This True HD IPS display has a Corning Gorilla Glass for protection. The LG Nexus 4 has a glass back similar to the one seen on the Apple iPhone 4. The phone runs on Android 4.2 Jelly Bean OS and is powered by a 1.5 GHz Quad-core Qualcomm Snapdragon S4 Krait Processor. Nexus 4 comes in two variants of internal storage, 8GB and 16GB. The powerful processor and display are complimented by 2GB of RAM. The Nexus 4 supports quad-band 2G and 3G networks and dual-band WiFi. The phone has Bluetooth 4.0, is NFC capable and has a microUSB port for entailing transfer of files efficiently.

The phone sports an 8 MP camera with auto focus, LED Flash and full HD video recording facility. The camera has additional features such a face detection, image stabilization, photo sphere and Geo-tagging. It gives an image resolution of 3264 x 2448 pixels and video recording of 1080p at 30 fps. This phone also offers a secondary front-facing camera of 1.3MP. The phone has a non-removable 2100 mAh standard Li-ion battery which provides 15 hours of talk time and 390 hours in stand-by mode. Its other features include GPS support, sensors like accelerometer, proximity and compass, active noise cancellation, image/video editor, voice memo and predictive text input.

Overview: The Chinese phone maker Gionee has once again set the airwaves ablaze with its successor to the Elife E6 smartphone. The Elife E7 is all about the camera, which the company claims to be the best Android camera phone in the market and this, is the USP of E7. The Elife E7 comes with a 16MP rear facing camera of higher than usual 1.34um pixel size which is supplemented with features like intelligent scene recognition, foot print mode, auto makeup effect and a meeting memo mode. The primary lens is based on the Largan M8 solution and is said to deliver sharp images. It has a 8MP front facing camera which allows the user to click good quality self portraits and for video calling. The Elife E7 sports a 5.5 inches full HD display with a resolution of 1920 x 1080 pixels (pixel density 401 ppi) which is quite sharp and the screen is equipped with Gorilla Glass 3. For comparison, the display is half an inch bigger than the Elife E6, but with the same resolution.

The model will be available in 2 variants: 4G LTE and 3G. Depending upon the variant, the phone may be sporting a 2.2GHz or 2.5GHz quad-core processor on a Snapdragon 800 chipset. The RAM will also depending upon the internal memory. That is, the 16GB variant comes with 2GB RAM on board and the 32GB variants is packed with 3GB RAM. The Gionee E7 comes with AMIGO 2.0 and runs Jellybean 4.2 which is a little older than the newest Android 4.4 that is already out in the market before the time of its launch. Theres also a sensor hub co-processor that along with a combination of three mics responds to voice commands, screen taps and gestures even when the phone is in standby. The juice for this mighty smartphone is provided by a 2,500mAh battery.

Pros: The curved back ensures that the phone sits well in your palm

Overview: Struggling smartphone company BlackBerry has launched a new phone called the Blackberry which maybe their last attempt to survive in the competitive market. BlackBerry Passport is in the shape of a square and has a 4.5 inches screen with the resolution of 1440x1440 pixels at 452 PPI. It has an all new keyboard which has a responsive touch surface like a trackpad and lets you perform many touch functions directly on the keyboard. You can scroll web pages, flick to type or slide along the keys to move the cursor, leaving the full screen space for viewing.

Internal storage of 32GB can be expanded to 128GB. The phone will run on BlackBerry OS 10.3 which comes with features like BlackBerry Assistant, BlackBerry Blend and Amazon Appstore.The rear camera is of 13 Megapixel and records 1080p HD video. It also has a 2 Megapixel front camera for video calls, etc. The phone comes with a powerful 3450 mAh non removable battery. This isnt a surprise as BlackBerry phones have always had good battery life. One looking to buy a flagship phone can also consider the flagship devices by other companies like Sony Xperia Z3, Motorola Moto Turbo,Samsung Galaxy S6 32 GB or the HTC One M9 Plus which runs on Android, too.

Overview: Huawei has been steadily gaining attraction with it's Honor brand focusing on high quality products at very competitive prices. One of which being the Huawei Honor 3X which is a flagship from the brand that offers quite good specs and is definitely priced aggressively.
Display and Design

Huawei Honor 3X has a 5.5 inch LCD Panel display with a resolution of 1280x720 pixels (HD) giving it a pixel density of 267PPI. Unfortunately, the display lacks Corning Gorilla Glass protection. The phone has a Plastic body design but has a robust build.
Hardware Specifications and Other Features

Talking about the performance, the Huawei Honor 3X runs on a MediaTek MT6592 Octa Core chipset clocked at 1.7GHz and paired along is 2GB of RAM which now sounds to be bare minimum. In terms of software the phone runs on Android 4.2 Jelly Bean out of the box with Huawei's UI running on top of it.

On the rear of the device sits a 13MP sensor that can record videos up to 1080p, whereas on the front you get a 5MP shooter for those selfies and video calling needs. The rear camera also has an LED Flash for taking shots in the dark. And to store all your pictures and other data you get only 8GB of internal storage that can be further expanded up to 64GB via a MicroSD card.

To power all this we have a 3000mAh battery that is removable which sounds decent enough to last through the day. The device supports Dual SIMs and takes Normal SIM only. The device lacks 4G connectivity.

In the similar price range there are other quite a few new entires that rock the latest chipset and are said to have a better camera with some other improvement features as well. The Nextbit Robin is the latest addition here that rocks a Snapdragon 808 processor, said to have a better camera with features like USB Type-C support and runs on the latest Android Marshmallow out of the box. Other good option to consider would be the Lenovo Vibe X3 that again runs on Snapdragon 808 and is definitely worth considering.

Overview: The Japanese smartphone company has added a mini version of Xperia Z1 to its high end or flagship series. Sony Xperia Z1 Compact has a smaller 4.3-inch Triluminos 720p display with X-Reality engine (the bigger sibling has a 5-inch 1080p display). Even with a 720p display, the smaller screen size translates to a crisp pixel density of 342PPI. It also ensures ease of single handed use.

On the hardware front it is similar to its big brother, similar in design with an aluminium border to give a premium feel. This waterproof phone has a 2.2 GHz quad-core Krait 400 processor with the latest Qualcomm MSM8974 Snapdragon 800 chipset to deliver powerful user experience. The dust resistant smartphone also comes with the latest Adreno 330 GPU (Graphics Processing Unit). The device has 2GB RAM and 16 GB expandable storage. The device has the same camera features as compared to its sibling, it has a 20.7-megapixel Exmor RS sensor, BIONZ processing engine and LED flash, supplemented with a 2-megapixel camera at the front. The device is capable of recording full HD videos at 1080p. Other features include-Back-illuminated sensor (BSI), Digital image stabilization, Face detection,Geo tagging, High Dynamic Range mode (HDR), Panorama and Scene modes.

The device runs on Android v4.3 (upgradable to v4.4 KitKat). The supports 3G and is available in many funky colours.The phone has NFC and other features such WiFi, Bluetooth as well.The miniature has a 2300mAh battery with Stamina mode (which is smaller than the 3000 mAh battery on the Z1, but the lower resolution display should help save some power). All in all, it is the first no-compromise mini verison of an Android flaghsip we've seen (the and have been stripped of certain features to achieve a lower price point than their bigger avatars).

The Neo 3 is a budget handset by Oppo. The phone has a 4.5 inch IPS display with a resolution of 854x480 pixels. The pixel density of the display is 266 PPI which is good for viewing content. The Oppo Neo 3 has a 5 megapixel primary camera with LED flash and a 2 megapixel front facing camera. The device runs Color OS loaded on top of Android 4.2 Jelly Bean. The OS is outdated and Oppo hasnt given any news about an update. The Neo 3 supports USB OTG which lets you connect a USB storage device to the phone. Oppos HotKnot feature allows you to transfer music, pictures and files at Wi-Fi speeds just by tapping the screens together. The phone has a tap to wake function where tapping the screen twice will switch it on. Gesture search allows you to launch apps by drawing a gesture on the screen. The Oppo Neo 3 is a dual-SIM device and has a removable 1900mAh battery. In the given price range, well recommend looking at the Asus ZenFone 5.

Overview: The Samsung Galaxy C5 is one of the very first devices in the 'C Series' of smartphones from Samsung. The series is primarily focused at coming up with smartphones with metallic body and no compromise specifications. Alongside the Galaxy C5, the Galaxy C7 is the other device in the C Series that we have already seen.
Display and Design

First look at the Samsung Galaxy C5 and you would be excused for mistaking it for the iPhone 6. In fact, the device also features the dreaded and much criticised rubber antennae lines that run on the back. As for the display, just like every high-end Android phone from Samsung, the display is drop dead gorgeous. You get a 5.2 inch screen with a Full HD resolution, giving the screen a pixel density of 424. Add to the fact that the display is Super AMOLED, the colours really pop out of the display.
Hardware and Features

Powering the Samsung Galaxy C5 is an Octa Core Snapdragon 617 chipset with Adreno 405 GPU. There is to keep your experience stutter free. You also have a fingerprint scanner on the home button. As for the internal storage, you have an option of picking either a 32GB or a 64GB variant. It should not prove to be too difficult a decision as the phone features a Hybrid SIM slot, which can double up as a slot for the MicroSD card. As with every Android phone made by Samsung, there is a custom TouchWiz UI on top. Below it is the latest Android 6.0.1 Marshmallow.

The rear camera on the Samsung Galaxy C5 features a 16 MP sensor. There is a dual tone LED flash on the rear to assist you with shooting when there is not sufficient light. The rear camera is capable of recording 1080p videos at 30fps. The front facing camera is an 8MP shooter. As mentioned above, the internal storage is either 32GB or 64GB depending on your choice, though you do get a slot to expand that storage using a MicroSD card of up to 128GB.

The Galaxy C5 features a non-removable 2600mAh Li-Ion battery. The battery should last you for a working day on moderate usage. Just like most modern day phones, the Samsung Galaxy C5 comes with a vast array of connectivity options. You have the likes of WiFi, Bluetooth, LTE, GPS, NFC all on board. This device has a hybrid SIM slot, so you can easily have two micro SIM cards in there with dual standby. You also get fest battery charging which promises to charge up to 83% of your phone in just 30 minutes.

The device competes in a very crowded segment of smartphones. You have the classic devices like the , which is a very stylish device with a near stock experience well as the likes of which comes with the latest Snapdragon 820 chipset. You could also look at devices like the , or which will be a very capable device to pick if you do not wish to invest in the Samsung device.

Pros: Well built body with just 6.7mm thickness
Cons: Rear camera does not shoot great pictures unless HDR mode used, HDR clicks at just 8MP

Pros: USB type-C port and fingerprint sensor

Overview: Apple iPhone 4 brought a pivotal change to the iPhone lineup in 2010. Doing away with the curved, plasticky body of the iPhone 3GS, the iPhone 4 sports a flat front-and-back glass body and an upgraded 5MP camera that takes good quality 720p HD videos. But the biggest industry-disrupting change was the high-resolution "Retina" display bearing a resolution of 960 x 640 pixels packed into the same 3.5-inch sized screen. This bore a PPI (Pixel Per Inch) of above 300, beyond which it is near impossible for the human eye to distinguish one pixel from another. They also added a front camera with their own video-calling application between Apple devices, dubbed FaceTime. Apple also introduced its own chip, the single-core A4 for the first time on the iPhone 4. The iPhone 4S got an upgraded dual-core A5 chip in 2011.

Pros: Retina display is probably the best display we have seen at the time of the launch of this phone
iOS 4 is fresh and brings tons of improvements
Apple's ecosystem has tons of apps and games
Cons: The glass on the back of the phone is prone to shattering

Overview: The LG G2 is the successor to the Optimus G Pro handset from the Korean electronics giant. LG has fitted everything but the kitchen sink in the G2. Starting with the 5.2-inch 1080p IPS display, bringing the display density count to a high 424 PPI. Next is the top-of-the-line Snapdragon 800 chip, bringing sheer brute force at 2.26GHz of clock speed on all four cores. That's paired with 2GB of RAM and either 16GB or 32GB of internal storage. There's no microSD expansion. Design-wise, the most striking thing is the placement of the volume and power buttons at the back of the device, right under the camera sensor. The fastest internet technologies are thrown in  LTE, 3G with speeds of up to 42Mbps and WiFi 802.11ac too.

At the back rests a 13 megapixel camera with Optical Image Stabilization (OIS), enabling less blurry snaps and better low-light performance. It can also record 1080p HD videos at 60 frames per second. It also has multiple mics and noise-cancellation for capturing better sound. On the software side, LG has added a few interesting features  Guest mode allows you to hand over the phone to somebody without them looking at your personal stuff, Audio zooming captures audio of a subject better as compared to the background sounds. There's a reasonably large 3000mAh Lithium Polymer battery which should keep all this mighty hardware running for long. This is the top-of-the-line, 32GB LTE version, that supports the Band 40 that Indian networks like Reliance Jio or Airtel use (2300 MHz).

Pros: Double tap to power on and off the screen are really handy
Very reliable camera even in dim lights
Thin bezels make the experience of using the phone nice
Cons: The power and volume buttons at the back take some time getting used to
Plastic build makes the phone feel a little cheap
The plastic back picks up scratches rather easily

Overview: The HTC One is the flagship model from the Taiwanese company for the year 2013. This handset encompasses HTC's best effort  and therefore the Matrix-inspired name, "The One". It's a stunning handset to look at, with its unibody aluminium body. The display is a 4.7-inch, Super LCD3 type with 1920 x 1080 resolution which translates to a whopping 496 PPI. Above and below that brilliant display are stereo speakers that belt out loud output with good clarity. Its more than adequately powered by the quad-core Qualcomm Snapdragon 600 chipset and an ample 2GB RAM. It comes in 32GB and 64GB capacities. The phone supports 4G LTE as well as WiFi's latest standard; 802.11ac. In the camera department, HTC's doing things differently. Enter UltraPixel  the sensor at the back of the HTC One can shoot only 4 megapixels, but the size of individual pixels in the sensor is twice the size found in good camera-phones like the iPhone 5 or 808 PureView. This, coupled with OIS (Optical Image Stabilisation), should give better low-light photography than typical camera-phones. There's also a 2.1MP front-facing camera with HDR support. Lastly, a 2300 mAh battery fit into the casing powers this beast of a handset.

The metallic unibody construction gives the device a very premium look

Cons: Camera really struggles to produce details giving generally a poor experience

Overview: The One is termed as the flagship killer manufactured by the company OnePlus. Much like the recent trend set by companies like Xiaomi, the company aims to provide flagship-grade features for a less than flagship price.

The OnePlus One has a 5.5 inch IPS display manufactured by JDI which is among the best manufacturers of display. Its a 1080p FULL HD display with a pixel density of 401 PPI. The device has a 13 megapixel Sony sensor with flash and a 5 megapixel front facing wide angle camera. The rear camera is capable of recording 4K video and also does 720p slo-mo videos at 120FPS. It has a Quad Core processor clocked at 2.5GHz, Snapdragon 801 for those who are curious and has 3GB of RAM on board. It runs CyanogenMod 11S, an Android fork based on version 4.4 KitKat that adds nifty features like Themes, Privacy Guard etc. Theres even a Moto X-like always-on listening feature where the phone will respond when you say Ok Snapdragon. Also, another similarity to the Moto X is an optional wooden back cover along with denim, linen etc.

There is an option to choose between 16GB and 64GB of internal storage but sadly no scope of expanding it. On the connectivity front the device supports many bands for 4G LTE which means that it should deliver the high-speed mobile internet in many countries (including India). It has a large 3100mAh battery on board which should provide decent backup. Abroad, the OnePlus One is sold only via an invite system.

Cons: The sandstone back tends to wear out with usage

The back panel is extremely difficult to remove and can easily break if tried

Overview: Xiaomi has started the new year with a new variant of the Mi 10. The mid-range device called the Mi 10i gets 5G network support, thanks to the new Qualcomm Snapdragon 750G chipset. The device gets a slew of interesting features, which includes 120Hz refresh rate display. The device features bezel-less display, quad rear camera, and the battery supports fast charging.

Overview: Oppo recently ventured into the Indian markets with its flagship device Oppo N1. Though its success is yet to be measured, Oppo treads forward with launching the Find 7, which will take on Samsung Galaxy 5 and Sony XPERIA Z2. Oppo Find 7 is a premium phablet thanks to its aluminum body (similar to HTC One) and top-notch hardware. It has a humongous 5.5 inch screen and is one of the first phones to feature a Quad HD resolution of 2560 x 1440 pixels, which boils down to a super high pixel density of 534PPI (the highest amongst current competition). Under the hood, there is a quad-core Snapdragon 801 processor (this processor is also used in the Galaxy S5 and XPERIA Z2), which clocks at 2.5GHz and is backed by an ample 3GB RAM. The hardware is powerful enough to ensure smooth multitasking.

On the camera front, the phone is equipped with a 13 megapixel sensor made by Sony. The smartphone is capable of capturing 4K (Ultra HD video) and slow motion videos (as seen in iPhone 5s). The phone comes with a Rapid Charger which enables the 3000mAh battery to charge within an hour. It is a Single-SIM phone and isn't water or dust proof unlike some of its competitors! Apart from this, it has all connectivity features like 4G and NFC.

Pros: Decent performance with Snapdragon 801 combined with 3GB RAM
Stereo speakers for good multimedia experience
Cons: Runs on way old Android version 4.3 Jelly Bean

The device has a good build quality and a stunning design that makes it look and feel premium. This power-packed offering is a real contender in its segment and a real value for money.

Overview: HTC Desire 700 Dual SIM, as the name suggests, is a dual SIM smartphone. It supports 2G/3G data networks and even CDMA. The Desire 700 has a 5-inch qHD (960 x 540 pixels) display, which is quite low when you get 1080p Full HD displays on phones costing thousands of rupees lesser. It weighs in at 149 grams. The phone is available only in Black color. It is powered by an unspecified Quad-core 1.2 GHz that aids the running of Android 4.2 or 4.3 (it is unclear at the time of writing this). There's barely acceptable 1 GB of RAM in it, again considering the price. The Desire 700 has 8 MP resolution on the rear camera with autofocus, and is coupled with an LED flash. There are basic camera features like geo-tagging, touch to focus, face detection, simultaneous HD image recording etc. HD videos can be also recorded at 1080@30fps. Also the secondary camera sports a 2.1MP BSI (Backside Illumination) sensor.

The smartphone's got an internal memory of 8GB which can be further expanded up to 64GB using microSD card. Other features that the phone has are Wi-Fi, Bluetooth v4.0 and has FM Radio. One good thing about this phone is the dual frontal stereo speakers with a built-in amplifier, much like the HTC One mini. The company claims that the Lithium Polymer battery of 2100 mAh used lasts Up to 582 hours in standby mode on 3G and Up to 11 hours 40 min of 3G talk time. The sensors used in this smartphone are Accelerometer, proximity and compass sensor. The launch price of the Desire 700 was a little over the top, but HTC has brought a massive price drop a few months after launch.

Cons: Entry level chipset in this price
No HD screen at this price point

Internally, it is not too different from the physically smaller Lumia 720. It has the same 800 x 480 pixel resolution, 512MB RAM and 8GB of internal memory, alongside the microSD card slot. The processor is a slightly faster 1.2GHz dual-core Snapdragon, while the camera is downgraded a little to a typical 5 megapixel sensor. But presumably thanks to the faster chipset, the Lumia 625 can record videos in Full HD 1080p resolution. There's a front-facing VGA camera for video-calling. Another star feature of this phone is the support for 4G LTE. The Lumia 625 runs the latest Windows Phone 8 smartphone OS and has the same 2000 mAh battery as the Lumia 720.

Overview: Apple delayed its yearly refresh for the iPhone in 2011 and launched the iPhone 4S in October. After a lot of hype and expectation, the iPhone 4S came with the same sized display as the iPhone 4 and retained the same glass body design. Disappointing many who expected a redesigned "iPhone 5", the 4S launch followed a similar pattern to the 3GS launch which carried the same design as the iPhone 3G, while upgrading the internals. The 4S brought an upgraded 8MP camera, faster dual-core A5 chip and a new voice assistant called 'Siri'. Apple also launched iOS 5 and its cloud offering iCloud along with the iPhone 4S. With increasing media content, apps, games and books, Apple also gave hardcore users a 64GB capacity since the iPhone 4S. The camera is capable of recording full HD videos, and the phone was lauded to be one of the best camera phones of 2011.

The One is termed as the flagship killer manufactured by the company OnePlus. Much like the recent trend set by companies like Xiaomi, the company aims to provide flagship-grade features for a less than flagship price.

The OnePlus One has a 5.5 inch IPS display manufactured by JDI which is among the best manufacturers of display. Its a 1080p FULL HD display with a pixel density of 401 PPI. The device has a 13 megapixel Sony sensor with flash and a 5 megapixel front facing wide angle camera. The rear camera is capable of recording 4K video and also does 720p slo-mo videos at 120FPS. It has a Quad Core processor clocked at 2.5GHz, Snapdragon 801 for those who are curious and has 3GB of RAM on board. It runs CyanogenMod 11S, an Android fork based on version 4.4 KitKat that adds nifty features like Themes, Privacy Guard etc. Theres even a Moto X-like always-on listening feature where the phone will respond when you say Ok Snapdragon. Also, another similarity to the Moto X is an optional wooden back cover along with denim, linen etc.

There is an option to choose between 16GB and 64GB of internal storage but sadly no scope of expanding it. On the connectivity front the device supports many bands for 4G LTE which means that it should deliver the high-speed mobile internet in many countries (including India). It has a large 3100mAh battery on board which should provide decent backup. Abroad, the OnePlus One is sold only via an invite system.

Useful customization available thanks to CyanogenMod

Overview: The new Moto X (2nd Gen or Moto X 2014) is the much-asked-for improvement over the original Moto X  which although not a commercial hit, was a darling among tech enthusiasts. Taking forward truly useful features like Touchless Controls, Active Notifications, the twist-to-open Camera Gesture, the new Moto X also satisfies most of the complaints people had with the original.

Starting with the display  which now has a 1080p resolution, while still being of the AMOLED type. But the screen size is bumped from 4.7 to 5.2 inches, increasing the dimensions also. It is now powered by the latest Qualcomm Snapdragon 801 quad-core 2.5GHz chip, while retaining the same 2GB RAM and 16GB or 32GB internal memory. The camera is also bumped up to 13 megapixels, and is complimented by a unique dual flash ring system. The camera can also record 4K video. It has a slightly bigger 2300mAh battery.

Now moving beyond specs, the Moto X 2nd Gen takes touchless controls to the next level, by allowing you to configure the phrase from the default Ok Google Now to anything you want. Next, you can also use voice to interact with third party apps like Facebook and WhatsApp. The phone also has two infrared sensors at the bottom that allow for gestures like waving your hand across the phone to show your notifications, or to silence a call or alarm. By the way, Active Notifications now also shows more than one notification.

The launch price suggests this phone will be in price range of the LG Nexus 5. Also, right now the Moto X 2014 is running Android 4.4.4 KitKat but has a guaranteed upgrade to Android L. This is the newly launched 32GB variant in India.

Pros: Solid acoustic experience from earpiece to speakerphone
Excellent build quality, feels good to hold
Very sharp Full HD AMOLED display with great color reproduction

Overview: The Nexus line up of smartphones are highly awaited every year, they kind of set the standard of what an Android Smartphone should be. The Nexus phone this year is designed and manufactured by Motorola, an ex-Google company now owned by Lenovo. Hence it is no surprise that the phone looks a lot like the Gen 2 Moto X.

The Nexus 6 is a huge device with a screen size of 5.96 inches sporting a Quad HD resolution of 2560 x 1440 pixels. The screen is dense and has a pixel density of 493PPI. The device is powered by a Qualcomm Snapdragon 805 processor which is a Quad-Core processor clocked at 2.7 GHz, the graphic processing is handled by the Adreno 420 which is currently the best in the market. The only downside is that its a 32-bit processor, which is unfortunate as Android 5.0 Lollipop that was launched with it was made 64-bit compatible. It now features front facing stereo speakers and should have a better output.

The Motorola Nexus 6 has a 13 megapixel primary camera with Optical Image Stabilization and Dual LED flash. It is also capable of recording 4K video at 30FPS. There is a 2 megapixel front facing camera for selfies and video conferencing. The Nexus 6 has a non-removable 3220 mAh battery and features Turbo Charging technology by Qualcomm. This allows the phone to charge faster effectively giving 6 hrs of juice by charging it for 15 mins. The device has a Nano-Sim slot and weighs 184 grams. Size-for-size, this phone will compete with the and the , but looking at the US launch price of $649, we think it might provide most value for your money in the high-end price bracket.

Just after 8 months of launching what seemed to be their flagship handset for the year 2013 (the XPERIA Z), Sony has already unveiled the XPERIA Z1 (codename Honami) to take the crown. While the humongous XPERIA Z Ultra caters to a different niche category, the Z1 is Sony's prime-time frontrunner. While the footprint of the Z1 is quite similar to the predecessor, the weight and thickness have gone up a notch. That is possibly owing to all the high-end components packed inside this phone. Design-wise, the XPERIA Z1 now has aluminium wrapped on all borders. While the screen is the same 5-inch 1920 x 1080 pixel TFT panel, the Z1 features Sony's Triluminous tech, which results in rich colour reproduction. The water and dust resistance is also upped a notch with IP58 certification. It is powered by the latest-and-greatest Snapdragon 800 chip, that features a 2.2GHz quad-core chip and powerful Adreno 330 graphics. To complement that is 2GB of RAM and 16GB of internal storage, with a microSD card slot for further expansion.

However, the highlight of the Z1 remains to be the 20.7 megapixel camera sensor at the back. Unlike the Z Ultra, this phone fortunately has an LED flash. It has a truckload of camera-related features, and both it and the front-facing 2MP camera can shoot 1080p HD videos. The battery size has also been increased to 3000 mAh, which should provide the phone all the juice it needs to power its high-end hardware. All possible connectivity options are thrown in, including LTE, WiFi 802.11ac, Bluetooth 4.0 etc.

The much awaited device iPhone 5 from Apple, has shown tough competition against Samsung's Galaxy S3. It is 18% thinner, 20% lighter and 12% less in volume as compared to the 2011 iPhone 4S. iPhone 5's LED-backlit TFT 4 inches Retina-display supports a resolution of 1136 x 640 pixels. This capacitive touch screen has an oleophobic coating and strength of Corning's Gorilla Glass. iPhone 5 gives an internal storage of 16/32/64GB and 1GB RAM. It runs on iOS 6 that brings Apple's own mapping capabilities to the iPhone. This phone is powered by Apple A6 chipset and has a dual-core processor of 1.2 GHz. For data and connectivity, iPhone 5 sustains ultra fast wireless features like 3G, Bluetooth v4.0 with A2DP and dual-band WI-FI.

iPhone 5 comes with an 8MP camera (known as iSight) has features like auto focus, LED flash, simultaneous HD video and image recording, Geo-tagging, face detection and a panorama mode. It gives an image resolution of 3264*2448 pixels. Also, its secondary front-facing camera of 1.2 MP enhances FaceTime video calls with 1080p HD video quality at 30 fps. The most pivotal change is the replacement of 30 pin adaptor to a simple Lightning connector which is more durable, and is reversible i.e. plugged in either way. Apart from this, iPhone 5 includes apps like Siri  the personal assistant, iCloud that gives instant access to your contents, Maps by Apple which are 3D interactive and the all new EarPods that come with your box of iPhone 5. It runs on a standard Li-ion battery of 1440 mAh which sustains up to 8 hours of talk-time and up to 225 hours in stand-by mode. It is available Black/Slate and White/Silver Colors. The iPhone 5 competes with Samsung's and range of smartphones.

Pros: Compact size helps for one handed use
Metal and Glass design makes it look and feel premium
Cons: Battery Life could have been better

Overview: Apple iPhone 4 brought a pivotal change to the iPhone lineup in 2010. Doing away with the curved, plasticky body of the iPhone 3GS, the iPhone 4 sports a flat front-and-back glass body and an upgraded 5MP camera that takes good quality 720p HD videos. But the biggest industry-disrupting change was the high-resolution "Retina" display bearing a resolution of 960 x 640 pixels packed into the same 3.5-inch sized screen. This bore a PPI (Pixel Per Inch) of above 300, beyond which it is near impossible for the human eye to distinguish one pixel from another. They also added a front camera with their own video-calling application between Apple devices, dubbed FaceTime. Apple also introduced its own chip, the single-core A4 for the first time on the iPhone 4. The iPhone 4S got an upgraded dual-core A5 chip in 2011.

Overview: The LG G Pro Lite is a mid-range phablet from the Korean phone maker; after showing their newly-regained strength in the high-end smartphone segment with the G2. The G Pro Lite features a 5.5-inch IPS panel but with a relatively low 960 x 540 pixel resolution. One distinction between the original G Pro and this model is the presence of a stylus, that fits into the shell of the phone. The G Pro Lite is powered by a dual-core 1GHz Mediatek MT6577 chipset, typically found on Android smartphones built by Indian phone makers, and now even appearing on multi-national brand handsets like the Sony XPERIA C. But the variant used in the LG G Pro Lite is lower than the Mediatek MT6589 quad-core variety typically seen. Coupled with that is 1GB of RAM and 8GB of internal storage.

Connectivity-wise, its got the basics covered  3G with speeds of up to 7.2 Mbps, WiFi 802.11n and Bluetooth 3.0 and also comes in a dual-SIM variant. In the camera department, this smartphone has an 8 megapixel rear-facing sensor and a 1.3MP front-facing one. The phone can record 1080p HD videos. The phone also has stereo speakers at the base. There's a massive 3140 mAh battery powering this phone, and given the comparatively non-intensive hardware components, we hope the battery life should shine. Competition from phablets priced nearby would include the Huawei Ascend Mate and the Samsung Mega 5.8.

Overview: The iPhone 5s takes over the role of the flagship iPhone from Apple in 2013. Replacing its predecessor the iPhone 5, the iPhone 5s maintains the same aluminum-clad design but now comes in three colour varieties, including a gold option. The iPhone 5s retains the same 4-inch 1136 x 640 pixel IPS panel. Internally though, there are drastic changes. It is powered by the new A7 chip, which Apple claims can be twice as fast as the A6. It is also 64-bit enabled and has the 'M7' co-processor dedicated for motion sensing  which can automate actions on the basis of what you're doing. The most unique feature Apple can boasting about the 5s is 'Touch ID'  a fingerprint sensor that's built into the home button. So, instead of having to punch in four-digit passcodes or alphanumeric passwords, Touch ID can authenticate the user by scanning his or her fingerprint.

Although the camera has the same 8 megapixels resolution, the sensor and aperture are larger. Also, there are LED flashes which have two different colour tones, which with the help of software fire aptly to accurately illuminate the subject. It can also record videos in an extremely high 120 fps frame-rate. While the iPhone 5 was an LTE 4G enabled phone, it only supported bands that were compatible in certain countries. The iPhone 5s brings in TD-LTE support, which has been adopted by operators in India and China. This is the middle variant with 32GB of internal storage.

Pros: Touch ID helps to keep the phone secure
Compact size helps for one handed use
Cons: Battery Life could have been better

Overview: The Nexus 5 is an LG-manufactured flagship phone from Google in 2013. It improves upon its predecessor, the Nexus 4, in many ways. Starting with the display  its got a 4.95-inch 1920 x 1080 pixel Full HD IPS panel covered with Gorilla Glass 3. Thats a whopping 445 PPI pixel density. It is powered by the latest-and-greatest Qualcomm Snapdragon 800 quad-core chip grunting at 2.3 GHz with an Adreno 330 graphics chip. Theres 2GB of RAM onboard and the Nexus 5 comes with either 16 or 32GB of internal storage (as with all recent Nexus handsets, theres no microSD card slot). Connectivity-wise, the Nexus 5 overcomes one of the shortcomings of the Nexus 4 with support for 4G (LTE) along with the latest WiFi 802.11ac and Bluetooth 4.0 support. Theres NFC and Wireless charging built-in as well.

In the camera department, the Nexus 5 sticks to the same 8 megapixel resolution of the prior model, but adds Optical Image Stabilization (OIS). Google also touts HDR+ which takes better High Dynamic Range images and Googles automatic image editing features. The phone also packs new sensors apart from the typical motion and light sensors; that include sensors for pressure and hall effect. Powering the Nexus 5 is a non-removable 2300 mAh battery. Lastly, the Nexus 5 comes with the brand new Android 4.4 KitKat which, other than feature additions, is optimised to use less resources than before. This is the high-end variant with 32GB of internal storage.

Pros: Excellent display with accurate colour reproduction
Compact size of the smartphone makes it very handy to use

Overview: Samsung Galaxy SIV (S4) is the 2013 flagship phone launched by Korean giant. The phone has plastic body that looks very similar to that of Samsung Galaxy S3 or Note II. It is available in Black & White colour. It boasts a 5 inch 1080p Super AMOLED screen, first of its kind in a smartphone. Samsung has announced two variations in processor  quad-core and octa-core and shall run on Android 4.2.2 (Android Jellybean). Each model shall come loaded with 2GB of RAM and shall support microSD expansion up to 64GB. The phone has a 13 megapixel camera unit with features such as dual shot (allowing you to take picture with front and rear camera at same time), drama shots (taking burst of photos and overlap them), cinema photo (allowing one part of photo to move while other is still), make GIFs and pre-made templates. The phone is backed up by a 2600 mAh Li-Ion battery pack.

Other features include S Translator (translates messages and emails to different languages), Air Gestures (lets you swipe/scroll pages without touching the screen with your finger), Air View (use your finger to hover over an email/date to see information behind), Smart Pause (Pauses a video when you look away from phone) and S Health (built-in pedometer, temperature and humidity sensors). The phone can also act as a combination of universal remote and visual TV guide. The group play feature allows you and your friends to play music or play multiplayer phones together. Galaxy S4 has three variants  16GB, 32GB & 64GB while the color options are - White Frost and Black Mist. The Galaxy SIV wages a feature-centric war against that released late 2012.

The 4S brought an upgraded 8MP camera, faster dual-core A5 chip and a new voice assistant called 'Siri'. Apple also launched iOS 5 and its cloud offering iCloud along with the iPhone 4S. With increasing media content, apps, games and books, Apple also gave hardcore users a 64GB capacity since the iPhone 4S. Overview: Honor 6X is the latest addition to Honor’s mid-range family, succeeding last year’s Honor 5X. Looks wise, it flaunts a metal body design mixed with a bit of plastic on the rear top and bottom. The device measures 150.9 x 76.2 x 8.2 mm and weighs 162 grams.

The Xiaomi Redmi Note 5 Pro was the most anticipated budget smartphone of the year. The brand managed to equip an all-new processor with a bump in RAM as well. Let's have a look at what this phone has to offer:
Display and Design

On the first look, the phone bears some aesthetic traits from the iPhone X. The camera on the back is arranged just like the one on Apple's flagship device. On the front, things change a bit. Thankfully, it doesn't have a notch on top of its display. The front of the phone does integrate a bezel-less design with a large 5.99-inch Full HD+ panel having an 18:9 aspect ratio and a resolution of 2160 x 1080 pixels. This makes the phone suitable for viewing all types of content. In terms of its build, it sports a metal unibody design with re-enforced corners to protect it from damage if it falls.
Camera and Software

The rear camera of the phone is one of its major selling points. The smartphone is fitted with a dual-rear camera setup which comprises of a 12MP primary sensor coupled with a secondary 5MP snapper. This allows the phone to use some software based enhancements to capture more aesthetic images. Up front, it has a 20MP sensor which is coupled with a selfie flash. The high-resolution camera allows for great selfies in both good as well as poor lighting. On the software side of things the phone ships with MIUI 9 based on . The Redmi Note 5 Pro is expected to in the following months.

Underneath its hood, the Redmi Note 5 Pro is powered by the all-new Snapdragon 636 processor which is a highly efficient chipset. This is coupled with a massive to breeze you through anything you can throw at it. On the storage side of things, this smartphone is packed with 64GB internal memory which can be expanded up to 128GB through its hybrid microSD card slot.

As far as connectivity is concerned, the phone allows for all the conventional solutions including 2G, 3G, 4G with VoLTE, Bluetooth, NFC and dual-band WiFi. To charge the phone and transfer data, you can do so through the micro USB port located on the bottom. Speaking of charging, it does support , so if you do happen to drain out its 4,000mAh battery before the end of the day, you can quickly top it up.

Overview: The much awaited device iPhone 5 from Apple, has shown tough competition against Samsung's Galaxy S3. It is 18% thinner, 20% lighter and 12% less in volume as compared to the 2011 iPhone 4S. iPhone 5's LED-backlit TFT 4 inches Retina-display supports a resolution of 1136 x 640 pixels. This capacitive touch screen has an oleophobic coating and strength of Corning's Gorilla Glass. iPhone 5 gives an internal storage of 16/32/64GB and 1GB RAM. It runs on iOS 6 that brings Apple's own mapping capabilities to the iPhone. This phone is powered by Apple A6 chipset and has a dual-core processor of 1.2 GHz. For data and connectivity, iPhone 5 sustains ultra fast wireless features like 3G, Bluetooth v4.0 with A2DP and dual-band WI-FI.

iPhone 5 comes with an 8MP camera (known as iSight) has features like auto focus, LED flash, simultaneous HD video and image recording, Geo-tagging, face detection and a panorama mode. It gives an image resolution of 3264*2448 pixels. Also, its secondary front-facing camera of 1.2 MP enhances FaceTime video calls with 1080p HD video quality at 30 fps. The most pivotal change is the replacement of 30 pin adaptor to a simple Lightning connector which is more durable, and is reversible i.e. plugged in either way. Apart from this, iPhone 5 includes apps like Siri  the personal assistant, iCloud that gives instant access to your contents, Maps by Apple which are 3D interactive and the all new EarPods that come with your box of iPhone 5. It runs on a standard Li-ion battery of 1440 mAh which sustains up to 8 hours of talk-time and up to 225 hours in stand-by mode. It is available Black/Slate and White/Silver Colors. The iPhone 5 competes with Samsung's and range of smartphones.

Overview: Samsung Galaxy M31 is an excellent device that comes with a beautiful design. It has a large bezel-less display that offers an impressive viewing experience. Under the hood, it offers a smartphone processing front that lets users enjoy games and other high-end usages. The device has massive battery support too, which makes it complete overall.

Being a mid-range smartphone it is packed with many features. The smartphone has a great configuration that ensures multitasking with ease. It has a good amount of storage space where the user can save files and documents. The cameras allow the user to capture sharp and highly detailed pictures and record high-resolution videos. The battery backup of the device is amazing and one can use it for a long time without worrying about dying out of battery.

The Sony Xperia C is the Japanese manufacturer's way of trying to compete with the onslaught of large, mid-range phones by Indian phone makers. It maintains the same design philosophy of the Xperia lineup and has a big 5-inch display, but with a comparatively low qHD (960 x 540 pixel) resolution. It is a dual-SIM handset with software settings that allow you to automatically set which SIM should be used what time of the day. Instead of Qualcomm, which is used in almost all of Sony's Android smartphones, the Xperia C is powered by a Mediatek MT6589 chip (the same that powers phones like the Micromax Canvas 4). It is a quad-core 1.2GHz CPU, complemented by 1GB of RAM and 4GB of internal memory (we trust about half of that should be available to the user). Using a microSD card, you can add up to 32GB more storage. The 3G speeds can soar as high as 42.2Mbps on this phone, and you have Bluetooth 4.0 and WiFi 802.11n support too.

The 8 megapixel camera at the back can shoot videos in 1080p Full HD. There's a VGA front-facing camera too. Sony claims the Exmor R tech and support for HDR and other camera-related software tweaks will set it apart from the crowd. Delivering juice to the Xperia C is a reasonably large 2370 mAh battery, which along with Sony's "Stamina Mode" battery-saving software feature, should deliver good up-time. It runs the fairly recent Android 4.2 Jelly Bean.
