Right since the very first Samsung Galaxy Note, the concept of phablets or smartphones that double up as tablets has only and only grown on people. The idea of having one device that is capable to replace two devices in your arsenal has indeed been a huge hit. Even the mighty Apple has been touched by the wave of phablets and hence we have the super giant iPhone 6 Plus and the 6s Plus. Known to be the Apple of China, Xiaomi has been active in the phablet space too, with the likes of the Redmi Note. The Mi Max takes the phablet game even more seriously. Here is more about the device.
Display & Design

One look at the Mi Max and you could be forgiven for thinking that the phone is more of a tablet than a smartphone. It features a mammoth 6.44 inch Full HD display, which gives with a sweet pixel density of 342PPI. This is perhaps one of the largest phablets at least in the terms of display size that exist today. On the design front, things are premium as the phone comes with an all metallic build quality. The edges of the phones are curved and you have a pretty standard candybar form factor going on here. There is absolutely no way, you should even attempt using this smartphone with one hand. Just like the Redmi Note 3, there is no information on whether the display has any sort of protection on it, so you are better off gripping the phone securely and using it with two hands.

Cons: Display visibility reportedly not great outdoors

Pros: Mammoth battery capacity with quick charging functionality

Overview: Despite being an affordable phone. the Coolpad Cool Play 6 packs a lot of power in its arsenal. The device comes with a powerful configuration along with an impressive 6GB RAM. Delivers a lag-free performance while running multiple tasks and can handle heavy graphics games with ease. The cameras are quite good considering the price tag. You get 64GB of storage, which is sufficient to carry enough content for your entertainment.

Pros: Dual rear cameras for capturing good images
Massive 6GB of RAM for seamless multitasking
Large battery that can easily get you over a day's use
Full HD display that can show content in 1080p
Cons: Heavily skinned Journey UI is filled with bloatware

Overview: The Asus Zenfone Max M2 64GB is another injection by Asus in its budget smartphone category and yet a powerful budget smartphone in general. The smartphone equips itself with a highly capable and power-efficient processor that with the combination of an ample RAM never fails to deliver an enhanced user experience. Moreover, this device comes with a good quality display and a fairly large battery that engross the user in durational usage sessions. The ability of this device to use the front camera for facial unlock and a highly responsive fingerprint scanner is enough to call it a real bang for the buck.

Sony replaced its well known Z-Series of smartphones with X-Series at MWC in 2016. The first batch of the phones features the Xperia XA alongside the flagship device, Xperia X. At the launch of the device, Sony confirmed its plans to bring the phone to United States in July and predictably the roll out in the Asia-Pacific region would be earlier. The phone features mid-range specs, which gives Sony a new ray of hope in a segment, that they have not done very well in, historically.
Display & Design

The display on the Xperia XA is a 5 inch unit with 720P resolution. This leads to a pixel density of about 293PPI. You are perfectly entitled to be a little disappointed with the display, as at its price, there are several phones that come with 1080P display. Look at the likes of OnePlus 2 or even the Moto X Play, which is almost an year old device now. The design of the phone is nothing much to write about either. The phone features a plastic build, even though in pictures it may give you a feeling that it is a metallic phone. You do get a edge to edge display with 2.5D curved glass that gives it a nice feel.

The smartphone is powered by the Helio P10 64bit octa-core chipset. There is just 2GB of RAM on board here. The combination is once again a little overwhelming especially for a phone that is priced at just above Rs 20,000 mark at launch. The combination of P10 and 2GB of RAM is not going to be powerful enough to get you through the heaviest games, sufficing at doing just your usual tasks like IMs, few pictures here and there and running not so intensive apps. There is no here. On the software side of the story, you will get Android  Marshmallow which is covered by the Xperia UI.

Sony has been well known for the cameras on their Z series devices. On the XA too, the camera looks excellent on paper at least. You get a Sony 13MP sensor with hybrid autofocus technology. This is a ⅓” sensor and is capable of shooting videos in 1080P videos. The front facing 8MP sensor should be enough for your selfie shots thanks to the ¼” sensor size. Just like the rear camera, the front facing camera can take videos in 1080P. The Xperia XA comes with 16GB internal memory. You do have a dedicated slot for memory expansion to up to 256GB.

Sony Xperia XA comes with a non-removable 2300mAh battery. If you are a heavy phone user, there is very little hope that you will be able to get through a day with this kind of a battery. The phone does come with a fast charger which promises to quickly charge your phone. The phone comes with support for Dual SIM and LTE connectivity on both SIM card. There is the usual set like WiFi, Bluetooth and GPS included. There is also no , so you will have to make do with microUSB for charging and syncing.

At its price point, we cannot help but feel that there are several phones that offer better value for money and more features. The likes of or even the are all not only more powerful phone but also come with modern day features like fingerprint scanner. If you want a phone with big battery, the would also be a good option above the Xperia XA Dual.

Pros: Edge to edge display makes swiping on the display a pleasure
Comes with the latest Android Marshmallow update out of the box
Cons: Not the smoothest of performer and the phone stutters when doing intensive tasks
Plastic build materials give the phone a cheap and inexpensive feeling

Overview: The previous HTC One (codename: M7) was a critically acclaimed smartphone of 2013. It is only unfortunate that it wasn't as big a commercial success to revive HTC's dwindling fortunes. Except for the lacking camera performance, the HTC One was otherwise a top-notch phone. And this year, HTC has built the next HTC One, keeping all the good things about the previous one. Called the HTC One (M8), this handset is a little narrower, a little shorter, a little thinner and has rounded corners and curvier edges at the back, which make it easier to hold. More importantly, now uses even little plastic in its body than its predecessor, being made almost entirely out of smooth aluminium. Screen size is bumped up a little to 5-inches, while still maintaining the 1920 x 1080 pixel resolution. It retains the front-facing 'BoomSound' stereo speakers, that are said to deliver even louder and richer sound than the original set on the HTC One. The buttons underneath the screen are gone, now replaced with onscreen buttons like the Nexus series.

It is powered by the latest Qualcomm Snapdragon 801 quad-core chip grunting at 2.5GHz. Paired with the same 2GB of RAM, it comes with 16GB or 32GB internal memory, and a microSD card slot to expand further. There are two cameras at the back that are used (the same 4MP UltraPixels type like the earlier One) to capture depth information. The Duo camera setup lets you change the focus point in an image after it is clicked. It features a duo-tone LED flash, much like the iPhone 5s, to retain natural skin colour tones. Unlike the or , the One M8 cannot record 4K videos (although the hardware is exactly the same, it does 1080p Full HD). Since the selfies trend is on the rise, there's a 5MP BSI sensor up front.

It runs HTC Sense 6 atop , that comes with an improved version of HTC's BlinkFeed and camera enhancements. There's a 2600mAh battery that should power this beastly hardware, along with an ultra power saving mode (like the Galaxy S5) that shuts everything off other than phone-calls, SMS and email. An interesting dotted flip cover shows basic info without having to open the flip. This is the model with 16GB of internal storage.

Pros: Excellent build quality and a solid feel to the device
The curvature to the back makes the phone sit very well in the hands
The stereo speakers on the front called BoomSound, give an amazing audio experience
Gorgeous display with good colour accuracy

Overview: After the rousing success of the Coolpad Note 3, the Coolpad Note 3 Plus and the Coolpad Note 3 Lite, the Coolpad Max is the first Coolpad smartphone in India to drop the Note 3 moniker. The smartphone stays true to its name and is a phone that features a large display making it useful for a lot of content consumption.
Display & Design

The Coolpad Max comes with a full metal body with an Aluminum alloy back. From the rear the device looks like a cross between the Huawei Nexus 6P and the iPhone 6s Plus. The front of the phone features a 5.5inch Full HD display with a sharp contrast ratio. This is protected by Gorilla Glass 4 and has a 2.5D curved glass just like the iPhone 6s, which makes swiping from the edges a pleasure.
Hardware and Features

The Coolpad Max is a slightly heavy device at 172 grams. It is powered by the Snapdragon 617 chipset and has 4GB of RAM. While not being the absolute top of the line processor, the Snapdragon 617 is a very decent mid-range SoC. The phone features a fingerprint scanner on the back for quick and secure unlocking.

The rear camera on the Coolpad max is a 13MP ISOCELL CMOS sensor while the front facing shooter is 5MP. You do have a dual tone LED flash on the back of the device to assist you when shooting in low light conditions. On the storage front, you have 64GB internal storage as well as a MicroSD card slot thanks to the hybrid SIM card slot that the device comes with. However, the device can only support up to 64GB of card, which is a bit of a bummer.

The Coolpad Max features a 2800 mAh battery, which is a non-removable unit. You can expect the phone to last you a complete day without major hassles. On the connectivity front, you do have Dual SIM connectivity where both the SIMs are 4G supported and have Dual Standby. Since the SIM slot is a hybrid slot, you can either use two SIM cards or one SIM card with one MicroSD card. Usual set of connectivity options like WiFi, Bluetooth, GPS etc are included.

The Coolpad Max at its price is a close rival to the which features a more capable Snapdragon 820 chipset. There is also the with stock Android available in similar price range, though the Nexus does not not have expandable storage. You can also make a case for the which although better spec’d than the Coolpad device, lacks a metallic body.

Pros: Excellent build quality that makes the phone feel very solid

Cons: Lacks 4K video recording on the primary camera
Since the processor is not the most powerful, heavy games struggle a bit
Mild heating on the device in the most common tasks

Talking about the performance, the LG Stylus 2 runs on a Qualcomm Snapdragon 410 Quad Core chipset clocked at 1.4GHz and paired along is 1GB of RAM which might ruin the overall smooth performance of the device. In terms of software the phone runs on Android 5.1 Lollipop out of the box with LG's UI running on top of it.

On the rear of the device sits a 8MP sensor that can record videos up to 1080p, whereas on the front you get a 5MP shooter for those selfies and video calling needs. The rear camera also has an LED Flash for taking shots in the dark. And to store all your pictures and other data you get 16GB of internal storage that can be further expanded via a MicroSD card up to 128GB.
To power all this we have a that is removable which sounds decent enough to last through the day. The device supports Dual SIMs and takes Micro SIM only. The device supports 4G & NFC connectivity.

The or looks like fairly competitive devices in this price range. The Redmi Note 3 specifically has a better processor and 3GB of RAM that boosts the performance of the device. Also in terms of camera, battery and other features the Xiaomi Redmi Note 3 looks like an overall winner here.

Overview: Taiwanese smartphone maker Asus has launched the ZenFone 5 in India at an unbelievable price. The ZenFone 5 is a brilliant looking device and the build quality is simply amazing. The phone is a Dual SIM device.

As the name suggests the device has a 5 inch IPS display with 1280x720 pixel HD resolution which takes the pixel density to 294PPI. The device is powered by an Intel Atom Dual core processor clocked at 1.6GHz and comes with 2GB of RAM. The phone has internal storage options of 8GB and 16GB which can be expanded to 64GB via a MicroSD card. Asus also offers 5GB of online web storage which is free for life.

Asus has a custom interface called the Zen UI and runs on top of Android 4.3 Jelly Bean. The interface is designed in such a way that it compliments the design of the phone. Asus has also preinstalled customized apps that let you calibrate the display. The device has an 8 megapixel primary camera with flash and a 2 megapixel front camera. The phone has a non-removable 2110mAh battery. For more internal storage, one can buy the Asus Zenfone 16GB variant. At this price point, it is going to give phones like the Moto G a tough time.

The OPPO A7 3GB RAM is a beautiful looking device that falls in the mid-range category. The waterdrop notch display over the bezel-less screen is an eye-catching feature, and with the slim body, it can attract a great deal of attention. The smartphone is a good all-round performer with good battery backup.

Decent Cameras and Good Enough Performance
Massive 5000 mAh Battery with Fast Charging
3.5mm Headphone Jack and USB Type-C Port

Overview: Xiaomi is known in India to disrupt the budget-smart phone segment with its popular Redmi Note Series. The Redmi Note 5 is the successor of the popular Redmi Note 4. Let's have a look at what the phone has to offer.
Display and Design

On the front, the phone deploys an all-new bezel-less design and features a 5.99 inch Full HD+ LCD display having a resolution of 2160 x 1080 pixels. This brings its pixel density up to about 400PPI. Xiaomi has managed to fit a larger screen in the same frame as that of the Redmi Note 4. This means that the phone is still compact and easy to handle. On the design front, the smartphone is built of a metal unibody frame which is also re-enforced on the corners to prevent it from denting if you happen to drop it.
Performance and Storage

Underneath its hood, the phone is powered by the Snapdragon 625 processor made by Qualcomm. This is the same processor that powered its predecessor and you can expect similar performance. It also comes with the Adreno 506 GPU to aid in enhancing graphics performance. In addition to that, the phone packs in 4GB of RAM to get you through all multi-tasking needs. On the storage side of things, the phone ships with 64GB of internal memory which can be expanded up to 128GB through a . If you are looking for better performance and up to 6GB of RAM, you should check out the , which was launched with this device.

In the optics department, the Xiaomi Redmi Note 5 features two camera modules located on either side of the phone. Its primary camera comprises of a 12MP snapper coupled with a dual-LED flash.  The camera is capable of recording Full HD videos and good images in well-lit environments. On the front is where its 5MP selfie camera is located. This is also coupled with front-facing flash which the Redmi Note 4 lacked. This means that capturing good selfies in poor lighting won't be a problem for this phone. On the software side of things, this offering comes with MIUI 9, which is the company's custom interface which is built on top of . The phone is likely to receive Android Oreo in the following months.

As far as connectivity goes, the phone checks all the right boxes and offers all conventional solutions including dual-band WiFi, Bluetooth, NFC and mobile connectivity up to 4G with VoLTE. In the battery department is where the phone truly shines. It has a large 4,000mAh battery unit which can easily last you over a day . Unfortunately, it does not come with fast charging, so it will take you a while to top the phone's battery up.

Pros: Out of the box it comes with Android Nougat and Oreo is expected soon.
The Snapdragon 625 processor is highly efficient processor allowing for good battery backup.
Cons: It does not come with a reversible USB Type-C port
Fast charging is not included with this phone.
It does not have a dedicated microSD card slot.

The BlackBerry Q10 is the first BlackBerry 10 OS phone featuring a hardware QWERTY keyboard. A model that can be considered as a successor to the Bold 9900, the Q10 supports LTE and has a sqaure-shaped 720 x 720 pixel Super AMOLED touchscreen. This resolution in a 3.1-inch screen size results in a 300+ ppi, thereby compliant to the "Retina" terminology. The Q10 is powered by a 1.5 GHz dual-core processor and 2GB RAM. There's 16GB of internal storage and it can be expanded with a microSD card slot to an additional 64GB. An 8MP shooter rests at the back that also takes 1080p videos and a 2.1MP front-facing camera belts 720p output which should come in handy for video conferencing. There's an ample-sounding 2100 mAh battery providing juice to these powerful internals. There's an HDMI port to connect the phone to a larger screen.

Overview: The new Moto X (2nd Gen or Moto X 2014) is the much-asked-for improvement over the original Moto X  which although not a commercial hit, was a darling among tech enthusiasts. Taking forward truly useful features like Touchless Controls, Active Notifications, the twist-to-open Camera Gesture, the new Moto X also satisfies most of the complaints people had with the original.

Starting with the display  which now has a 1080p resolution, while still being of the AMOLED type. But the screen size is bumped from 4.7 to 5.2 inches, increasing the dimensions also. It is now powered by the latest Qualcomm Snapdragon 801 quad-core 2.5GHz chip, while retaining the same 2GB RAM and 16GB or 32GB internal memory. The camera is also bumped up to 13 megapixels, and is complimented by a unique dual flash ring system. The camera can also record 4K video. It has a slightly bigger 2300mAh battery.

Now moving beyond specs, the Moto X 2nd Gen takes touchless controls to the next level, by allowing you to configure the phrase from the default Ok Google Now to anything you want. Next, you can also use voice to interact with third party apps like Facebook and WhatsApp. The phone also has two infrared sensors at the bottom that allow for gestures like waving your hand across the phone to show your notifications, or to silence a call or alarm. By the way, Active Notifications now also shows more than one notification.
The launch price suggests this phone will be in price range of the . Also, right now the Moto X 2014 is running Android 4.4.4 KitKat but has a guaranteed upgrade to Android L.

Overview: Lately Gionee has been focusing on phones that pack a massive battery to address the industry's major problem. The Gionee Marathon M5 Plus is yet another device to sport a huge battery of 5020mAh. Apart from the battery the device also packs some decent specifications but unfortunately does not justify the overall package for the price the Gionee Marathon M5 Plus is offered.
Display and Design

On the front of the device sits a 6 inch AMOLED display with a resolution of 1920x1080 pixels. The display size does sound huge and definitely not for people looking for one hand usage, however people looking for a great multimedia experience are in for a treat here. The display is sharp & crisp enough at 368PPI to not see any pixelation. In terms of build quality, the Gionee Marathon M5 Plus rocks a Metal Unibody design.
Hardware and Features

In terms of performance, the specifications look merely average and nothing worth the price to expect any exceptional performance. Gionee Marathon M5 Plus comes with a MediaTek MT6753 Octa Core chipset which is clocked at 1.3GHz and paired along is 3GB of RAM. The phone's operating system is based on Android 5.1 Lollipop out of the box with Gionee's Amigo UI 3.1 running on top of it. The phone also has a embedded in the home button on the front.

For photos, you get a 13MP sensor on the rear of the device with an LED Flash, whereas on the front lies a 5MP camera for those selfies and video calling needs. The rear camera can record videos up to 1080p @ 30fps. Talking about the storage, you get ample 64GB of internal storage to store all your data and in the rare case if you still run out of space, you can expand the storage up to 128GB more via a MicroSD card.

Like mentioned earlier, the Gionee Marathon M5, as the name rightly suggests is capable of running a long marathon with it's massive 5020mAh battery. And talking about connectivity, the phone supports Dual GSM+CDMA setup both needing to be a Micro SIMs. It is a 4G enabled device with as well.

For the price of around Rs. 27,000 you can definitely get a far better performing device like and the likes, however if you are specifically looking for a big battery device with a huge 6 inch display then the Gionee Marathon M5 Plus is worth considering.

Pros: Huge 5020mAh battery keeps it powered on for a really long time

Design and Display

Hardware and Features

In terms of performance the Lenovo Phab Plus is running on a Qualcomm Snapdragon 615 Octa Core chipset that looks to be underclocked at 1.5GHz to tackle the know heating issue with the chipset. Combined along you get 2GB of RAM which is bare minimum for a device to perform smooth multitasking. You get a 13MP shooter on the rear of the device that can record videos up to 1080pixels, whereas on the front you have 5MP sensor for those selfies and more importantly for a good video calling experience. Next to the rear camera of the device also lies a Dual Tone LED Flash light for those natural looking night shots. To store all the data, there is 32GB on internal storage that can be further expanded up to 64GB via a MicroSD card.

The Lenovo Phab Plus accepts Dual Nano SIMs and supports 4G LTE in India. And to power all this you have a 3500mAh battery that is sealed inside the device. The battery capacity does sound good enough and should last through a full working day.

Overview: The A-series by Oppo is primarily focused at producing good budget range smartphones. These phones appeal to those who are looking to get the best value for their buck. The Oppo A37 was made official globally around June 20th of 2016 and has pretty much everything that you would expect from a moderately powerful Android phone today.
Display & Design

The Oppo A37 comes with a 5-inch display with 720P resolution. This is an IPS LCD panel, so the colours are true and have good legibility outdoors. Despite being a strictly budget phone, there is a 2.5D curved edge on the phone, something that we have seen on flagship phones like HTC 10 and iPhone 6s. There is also Gorilla Glass 4 on the top, ensuring that your display is well protected. In terms of the design overall, the A37 comes with a candy bar design that is fairly common today. Clear to see, Oppo has taken inspiration from iPhone 6 while designing this device. The edges are nicely rounded and you have neat rounds along the corners too.

The Oppo A37 is powered by chipset, and there is 2GB RAM to assist the chipset in order to help you breeze through your tasks. With the combination, you should not expect the phone to play heavy games very well, but it should be able to hold up on its own for the regular day to day tasks. There is no fingerprint scanner here. On the software front, the A37 is still running the dated Android version 5.1, though there is ColorOS 3.0 on top, which sure adds some interesting features.

The rear camera on the phone is an 8MP sensor. This is a f/2.2 aperture lens, which at least on paper does not look very enticing. The rear camera is capable of creating a 24MP image using the Ultra HD mode on the phone. The front-facing camera is a 5MP sensor with f/2.4 aperture. The 1.4-micron pixel size on the front is really good for your selfie needs. There is also a screen flash on the phone. The Oppo A37 comes with 16GB internal storage, though you do have a dedicated slot for expanding the storage via a .

Due to a rather thin chassis at 7.7mm, the device houses a 2630 mAh battery, which is not the biggest. However, since it is powering just a 720P display and a rather low power chipset, you should expect a day from the phone. There is support for Dual SIM card on the phone, both of which have LTE connectivity. You have your usual set of connectivities like WiFi, Bluetooth and GPS on board.

In the budget category, if you are not looking to pick the A37, you could give devices like the or even the Zuk Z1 a sound consideration. There is also the or the if you are looking for a more stock experience, with a more powerful internals on the phone.

Pros: HD display with Corning Gorilla Glass 4 protection
3 slots available for 2 SIMs and a microSD card
Cons: Battery capacity could have been better
Heats up at times while playing games

Overview: With more than 6.5 million units shipped, Moto G became the most sold Motorola phone ever. The phone offered stock Android and decent features at a very reasonable price. The major spec bumps that the Moto G 2nd Gen has over its predecessor is a bigger screen and an improved camera.

The new Moto G sports a 5 inches LCD screen at 1280x720 resolution hence its pixel density is a bit lower at 293.7PPI. It also has a new 8MP rear camera and a 2MP front camera as compared to the 5MP and 1.3MP respectively, in last years version. The speaker that was placed on the back of the earlier Moto G is now on the front and one more speaker has been added. These stereo speakers will help improve sound output. Besides, the phone has 16GB of internal storage and Moto has also given a microSD card slot. It comes with 1GB RAM and is powered with a 1.2GHz Quad core Snapdragon 400 processor. The phone also offers dual SIM facility. Battery capacity remains unchanged at 2070mAh. This phone will directly compete with the Asus Zenfone 5. As the Moto G 2013 is discontinued, the phone is priced at Rs. 13,000 at launch.

Pros: Improved camera performance over the 1st gen
Near stock android keeps things snappy

Overview: The Moto G is an entry-level smartphone from the now Google owned phone maker Motorola. Having exit markets like India in the past before the acquisition, this will mark the companys re-entry once the Moto G starts selling here in January 2014. The Moto G comes in colourful rear shells that are replaceable. sports a 4.5-inch 1280 x 720 pixel LCD touchscreen. At its heart, theres a Qualcomm Snapdragon 400 chip, with four cores running at 1.2GHz each. Theres a reasonable Adreno 305 graphics chip onboard as well. Coupled with the chip is 1GB of RAM and either 8 or 16GB of internal memory. Sadly, the Moto G will be one of the very few inexpensive handsets to not have a microSD card slot. This 3G enabled handset can deliver speeds of up to 21 Mbps and has WiFi 802.11n and Bluetooth 4.0 support.

Theres a 5 megapixel auto-focus camera with an LED flash at the back, accompanied by a 1.3MP front-facing camera. The phone can record videos in 720p HD. FM Radio also makes it to the feature-list, winning the hearts of people who still desire for this feature. Although the phone runs Android 4.3, it is said to run the latest Android 4.4 KitKat by the time it launches in India. Theres a 2070 mAh non-removable battery which Motorola quotes can deliver an all day battery life. The Moto G is said to have an attractive price point for the features offered; hopefully under the Rs. 15,000 mark for the 16GB capacity. This is the 8GB variant, which we think will give the likes of the or the a run for its money.

Pros: Near stock Android experience with promise for quick updates in future
Compact size, which makes the phone usable with one hand
Cons: The camera performance leaves a lot to be desired

Overview: The BlackBerry Q5 is a mid-range, and currently the cheapest offering running BlackBerry 10 OS. When compared to the premium BlackBerry Q10, there are a few changes that distinguish the two. First and foremost, the Q5 is more youthful-looking, differs in the design of the QWERTY keys and has a plasticky appearance. The Q10 is a world-phone supporting both CDMA and GSM networks, but the Q5 supports only GSM. But on the bright side, it retains LTE; the next generation high-speed internet technology. Instead of Super AMOLED, BlackBerry has chosen to go with an IPS touchscreen panel in the Q5, but maintains the same 720 x 720 pixel resolution in a 3.1-inch screen size. Memory is halved to 8GB, and the processor is a slightly slower 1.2GHz dual-core variant (the Q10 has a 1.5GHz dual-core). But both fortunately have 2GB of RAM. The camera is also downgraded from an 8MP sensor to a 5MP one at the back, but the Q5 has the same 2MP front-facing camera for video calls. Battery capacity is almost the same at 2180 mAh.

Pros: The physical keyboard is one of the best keyboards to type on mobile
Battery backup easily gets you by a whole day
Screen is bright and colours are true, good outdoor visibility
Due to the space between screen & top of keyboard, there is room for gestures unlike on Q10
Cons: The squared aspect ratio of the screen is awkward and takes time to get used to
App ecosystem on Blackberry in general is poor
The design has no flair and the phone feels a little cheap
Performance is not the most fluid, as there are stutters in UI

Overview: Xiaomi is a relatively new Chinese smartphone maker that has made headlines around the world. Xiaomi has made Mi3 by compiling some of the best components available on the planet. It boasts a 5 inch IPS HD Display with a resolution of 1920x1080 pixels which translates into a crispy pixel density of 441PPI. The display is made by either Sharp or LG, both of which are known to supply displays to Apple for its iPhone and iPad. It is known to have great viewing angles and colours appear vibrant. Under the hood, there is a Quad-core Qualcomm Snapdragon 800 processor which clocks at 2.3GHz. The processor is paired with 2GB RAM and backed by an Adreno 330 GPU. The chipset is very powerful and capable enough to churn any task thrown at it efficiently. Similar hardware is used in the Google Nexus 5.

Xiaomi Mi3 sports a 13 Megapixel Exmor sensor which is provided by Sony. The snapper has been aided by a Dual-LED flash (made by Philips), which will enable the device to capture good images even in low-light conditions. The smartphone even supports Full HD video recording as well. Also, there is a 2 megapixel secondary camera included for video calling and selfies. The only drawback of this phone is that it supports Single-SIM. We just hope that this does not become Achilles Heels for Xiaomi. On the Connectivity front it offers Bluetooth, WiFi, GPS, NFC etc. There is no 4G connectivity. The beast is powered by a 3050mAh battery, which as per company claims should allow the user to surf seamlessly for 21 hours on 3G network. It comes in two variants, 16GB and 64GB of internal memory but lacks an external card slot.

Vivo Y21 is a budget oriented device, but focusing more on design, Vivo fails to offer what other manufacturers focus to offer and that is a decent hardware for the phone to perform well. The Vivo Y21 clearly does not match up to the other competing devices in the similar price range in terms of hardware.
Design and Display

Design is the only criteria where the Vivo Y21 excels. Even though the phone is plastic, the design of the phone makes it feel and look premium with solid build quality. Coming to the display is where is the phone begins to disappoint, it has a 4.5 inch display with a resolution of 854x480 pixels giving the display a pixel density of about 218PPI.
Hardware details

Running inside the Vivo Y21 is a MediaTek MT6580 Quad Core chipset and paired with it is just 1GB of RAM. And coming to the software part, the phone's operating system is based on Android 5.1 Lollipop out of the box with Vivo's FunTouch OS 2.1 running on top of it.

In terms of camera, the phone has a 5MP rear camera sensor that can record videos up to 720p and on the front lies a very basic 2MP camera sensor. To store all your data, you get 16GB of internal storage with an expansion option of up to 128GB via a MicroSD card.

On the back we have just a 1900mAh battery that is user replaceable but sounds just about average and we doubt if it would last you through the day. Coming to connectivity, the phone supports Dual Micro SIMs and yes, the device is 3G enabled.

Pros: Battery is user removable so you can swap it for a fresh one if it runs out of charge.
Cons: 1GB of RAM is insufficient for heavy multitasking
Android lollipop that comes with the phone is outdated
Funtouch OS feels like a cheap knock off of iOS

Since the phone is available only in black colour, it does manage to look classy, despite barely anything significant about it from the design perspective. The screen on the phone is a 5-inch IPS panel with a resolution of 1280x720 pixels. This equates to a pixel density of 294PPI. There is Gorilla Glass protection on the phone, so if you drop your phone too often, there would be at least some protection.
Hardware and Features

In the engine room of the Era X is a Quad-core, 1.5GHz Spreadtrum SC9830A chipset. There is Mali 400 GPU for handling the graphics onboard. Xolo has included 2GB of RAM on board too. On paper, the specifications look fairly modest, and something that you should expect in this price. However, if you have your reservations against the Spreadtrum processor, there is the Xolo Era 4K with a MediaTek chipset which is a good pick in the price range. The phone runs Android 5.1 Lollipop at launch, but Xolo has explicitly stated that the phone can be upgraded to Marshmallow. The phone also brings with it support for several Indian languages such as Assamese, Bengali, Gujarati etc.

The camera on the Xolo Era X is a 8MP sensor on the rear with an LED flash. The front facing shooter is a 5MP camera with an LED included. This should be sufficient for the needs of your selfies and video chatting. There is only 8GB of storage on board though, you can expand the same using a MicroSD card. The phone supports up to 32GB of MicroSD card.

Since the battery of the Xolo Era 4K is removable, you will be able to carry a couple of spare units with you and replace them in case you do not have immediate access to your charger. This does not hide away from the fact that the 2,500mAh battery unit is not really going to be something that would please those who are looking for long spells on their phones, sans the charger. You do have 4G LTE connectivity here. There is WiFi, Bluetooth as well as MicroUSB port for data charging and syncing. You have an FM player in built as well as support for Dual SIM card on the phone.

In the sub , there are a few phones that you should consider before you are sold on to picking up the Era X. There is the and the which outperform the Era X. You can always extend your budget and pick the or the , if you want a phone with a fingerprint scanner.

Overview: The LG G3 comes in less than a year after the well-received LG G2 was launched. While the G2 was packed to the gills with features, the LG G3 adds even more. For starters, the display is a little bigger at 5.5 inches, but now features an extremely high Quad HD (2560 x 1440 pixel) resolution. This bumps up the pixel density to a whopping 534PPI, making it one of the crispiest screens on the planet right now. Technically, the human eye cannot perceive the difference between pixels beyond 300 PPI pixel density, so despite the predecessor already having crossed that barrier (at 424PPI), we wonder how much of a benefit users will be able to notice with the bumped up resolution. Moving on, its powered by the Snapdragon 801 quad-core 2.5GHz chip, which is the gold-standard for Android flagships right now. Much like Gionees Elife E7, the LG G3 comes in two variants  a 2GB RAM unit with 16GB internal storage, and a 3GB RAM unit with 32GB memory. Whichever may be your preference, there is a microSD card slot on both models to accommodate up to 128GB more storage capacity. Design-wise, the G3 retains the placement of the power and volume buttons at the back of the device, around the camera lens. The metallic back now makes the phone look more appealing, and is available in more colour options (including Gold).

It maintains the 13MP camera sensor with Optical Image Stabilization at the back, but adds a two-tone flash (much like the iPhone 5s and the HTC One M8). But one unique camera feature is the laser-assisted auto-focus; a sensor on the other side of the camera lens that actually fires lasers to ascertain the distance between the subject, resulting in an extremely fast focusing and capturing of photos. Theres also a 1-watt speaker with a boost amplifier that should deliver loud and clear audio output. The 3000mAh battery is now removable and the phone now supports wireless charging too. LG has also flattened their software UI overlay which runs atop Android 4.4 KitKat.

They also sell the LG Circle Case; a flip cover with a circular viewing area when the flip is closed, and a special circular UI assists in using the phone without opening the flip cover. All in all, the LG G3 raises the bar for flagship Android phones for the year 2014, and technologies like Quad HD displays should become standard when the next batch of competition launches.

Overview: Asus, the Chinese smartphone manufacturer has launched the Asus ZenFone Go in the sub 10,000 category where the other Chinese manufacturers like Xiaomi, Lenovo and Coolpad are already facing cut throat competition. The Asus ZenFone Go (ZC451TG) looks like an average performer when it comes to the specifications of the device.
Display and Design

Asus Zenfone Go (ZC451TG) has a 4.5 inch LCD Panel display with a resolution of 854x480 pixels giving it a pixel density of 218PPI. Unfortunately, the display lacks Corning Gorilla Glass protection. The phone has a Plastic body but the build looks to be firm and good to hold.
Hardware Specifications and Other Features

Talking about the performance, the Asus Zenfone GO (ZC451TG) runs on a Qualcomm Snapdragon 200 Quad Core chipset clocked at 1.2GHz and paired along is only 1GB of RAM. In terms of software the phone runs on Android 5.1 Lollipop out of the box with Asus's  Zen UI running on top of it. There has been information about if the device is supposed to receive Android Marshmallow update.

On the rear of the device sits a 5MP sensor that can record videos up to 720p, whereas on the front you get just a 0.3MP shooter which can is quite below average in terms of picture quality. The rear camera also has an LED Flash for taking shots in the dark. And to store all your pictures and other data you get 8GB of internal storage that can be further expanded via a MicroSD card up to 64GB.

To power all this we have a just 2070mAh battery that is not removable and sounds below average as we doubt if it will last through a whole working day. The device supports Dual Micro SIMs. The device lacks 4G connectivity.

Pros: The device is handy at 4.5 inch screen size
Cons: Average battery life with just 2070mAh unit

Overview: The Nokia Lumia 630 sounds like the successor to the Lumia 620; a decent handset which got somewhat sidelined by the popularity of the Lumia 520 worldwide. The screen size is bumped up to 4.5-inches, but the resolution still remains the typical 854 x 480 pixels. This is the first Windows Phone to have software buttons, and also the first one to not have a dedicated camera shutter button. The chipset is now a more powerful quad-core Snapdragon 400 running at 1.2GHz. It has 512MB of RAM, which might sound insufficient while playing high-end games or apps, but should be just fine for typical usage.

Theres 8GB of internal memory with a microSD card support for up to 128GB. This is great because with Windows Phone 8.1, Microsoft has enabled installation of apps to the SD card. The Lumia 630s got a run-of-the-mill 5 megapixel AF camera at the back, but unfortunately misses out on the LED flash, just like the Lumia 520. Not only does the LED flashlight help in taking low-light pictures, it also comes in handy as a torch. Theres no secondary video-call camera either, which again is disappointing given the deep integration of Skype in Windows Phone 8.1. The battery capacity has been bumped up to 1830mAh, should help offset the higher-performance chipset.

The Yu Yutopia is the most power packed smartphone that we have seen from Yu, at least so far in 2016. After playing strong in the mid-range and budget category, Yu announced the Yu Yutopia to primarily take on the likes of the OnePlus 2 in a bid to be a true flagship killer. However, with launch delays and later complains of a poorly optimized software the phone did not reach the heights it was expected to.
Display and Design

The Yu Yutopia features a regular candybar design with metallic body that we have seen on several modern day smartphones. It is a borderline seen it all design, which may seem a little boring to you. The front of the phone is dominated by a 5.2 inch IPS LCD display. The screen resolution is 1440x2560, giving it an incredible pixel density of 565 PPI. The display is protected by Corning Gorilla Glass so you can be secure about the display.
Hardware and Features

The Yu Yutopia is powered by the flagship Octa Core, Snapdragon 810 chipset. There is 4GB of RAM and in combination with a fast chipset, the Yu Yutopia should be able to handle most tasks thrown at it effortlessly. In its price range, the Yu Yutopia is perhaps the most powerful smartphone there is, but what hurts the phone is that out of the box it comes with Android 5.1.1 rather than Marshmallow. Although the UI is very close to stock Android, the software is not best optimized, which leads to a stuttery performance. You get a fingerprint scanner on the back of the Yu Yutopia. This fingerprint scanner can double up as a camera shutter button for taking selfies.

The rear camera on the Yu Yutopia features a 21MP Sony IMX230 sensor with OIS and Phase Detection Autofocus. The rear camera is capable of recording videos in 4K at 60fps. The front facing camera is an 8MP sensor, which should do well to suffice your need for a good selfie phone. For all the pictures you take, there is a generous 32GB internal memory on the Yutopia. You can further expand this by a MicroSD card, which can be inserted into the slot 2 in the SIM tray.

The Yutopia comes with a non-removable 3000 mAh Li-Po battery. This should last you a day on a single charge, but you will have to carefully manage it. If you do run out of the battery, there is support, which will enable you to charge about 60% of the battery in three hours or so. The device has a hybrid SIM that lets you to either use two SIM cards simultaneously or just stick to one SIM card and a MicroSD card. On the connectivity front, you get a Micro USB connector at the bottom. LTE support is available as is WiFi, Bluetooth and GPS.

As mentioned already, the Yu Yutopia competes against the as the ultimate flagship killer. However, if you are looking for a slightly more powerful device in the range, you should consider the . Also, the or the albeit with a slightly inferior chipset but better optimized software would be a smart pick.

Cons: Heats up while playing games or recording videos
